headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2014 Conference Call. Today's date is February 10, 2015, and this call is being recorded.The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, in
componenttext:
Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2014 Conference Call. Today's date is February 10, 2015, and this call is being recorded.
The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, including, without limitation, those regarding projections of future revenues or earnings, operating margins, operating expenses, product development, new markets or prospects for the company solutions and plans and expectations related to the acquisition of Siemens Health Services. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by the forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements may be found under Item 1A in Cerner's Form 10-K together with the company's other filings.
Reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed in this earnings call can be found in the company's earnings release, which was furnished to the SEC today and posted to the investor section of cerner.com.
This time, I'd like to turn the call over to Marc Naughton, Chief Financial Officer of Cerner Corporation. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alex. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call. I'll lead of today with a review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with the results, highlights and marketplace observations; Mike Nill, Executive Vice President a
componenttext:
Thank you, Alex. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call. I'll lead of today with a review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with the results, highlights and marketplace observations; Mike Nill, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, who will discuss operations; Neal Patterson, our Chairman and CEO is traveling; Jeff Townsend, Executive Vice President and Chief of Staff here our investment community HIMSS and looks forward to providing an update on our rollout of solutions in Intermountain Healthcare and our strategic alignment with them we believe will broadly benefit Cerner, Intermountain Healthcare and our client base.
Now we will turn to our results. Overall, we had a solid Q4, very strong year. We have a good outlook for 2015 and beyond. Our total bookings revenue in Q4 was $1.16 billion, which is an all-time high and reflects 5% growth over Q4 of '13. Bookings margin in Q4 was $982 million or 85% of total bookings.
For the full year, bookings revenue was $4.25 billion, up 13% over 2013. Bookings performance drove a 19% increase in total backlog to $10.62 billion. Contract revenue backlog of $9.79 billion is 20% higher than the year ago. Support revenue backlog of $826 million is up 5%. Revenue in the quarter was $926 million, which is up 16% over Q4 of '13. The revenue composition of the Q4 was $280 million in system sales, $197 million in support and maintenance, $431 million in services and $81 million in reimbursed travel.
For the full year, revenue grew 17% over 2013 to $3.4 million.
System sales revenue reflects a 14% increase over Q4 of '13, strong growth in technology resale and good growth in software revenue. For the full year, system sales revenue grew 12% over 2013 led by software growth of 17%, which was partially offset by lower full year technology resale growth of 4%. Subscription revenue grew 12% for the year.
Q4 system sales margin dollars grew 11% over the year-ago period, and full year system sales margin dollars grew 16% over 2013, reflecting continued strong levels of higher-margin system sales components, like software and subscriptions.
Moving to services. Total services revenue was up 19% compared to Q4 of '13, and 23% for the full year, with strong growth in professional services, Managed Services and ITWorks.
Support and maintenance revenue increased 16% over Q4 of '13 and 9% for the full year. Higher growth rate in Q4 reflects the impact of the quarter having 14 weeks instead of our typical 13 weeks. Note that the revenue benefit of the extra week was minimal for professional services and system sales, as we had low Professional Services utilization during the extra week due to the holiday and system sales is mostly nonrecurring revenue.
Looking at revenue by geographic segment. Domestic revenue increased 14% and Global revenue grew 34% over Q4 of '13. The higher rate of Global growth in Q4 was driven by strong software and technology resale as well as continued growth in Global Managed Services.
For the full year, domestic revenue grew 18% and Global grew 6%.
As a preview tot he annual update of our detailed business model that we'll provide at our Investment Community Meeting on April 14 at HIMSS, I'd like to provide you with the total revenue and growth by business model for the full year 2014.
Licensed software grew 17% to $453 million. Technology resale grew 4% to $273 million. Subscriptions and transaction increased 12% to $220 million. Professional services revenue grew 28% to $1.09 billion. Managed services increased 15% to $549 million. Support and maintenance was up 9% to $725 million. And reimbursed travel was $90 million, which is up 28%.
Moving to gross margin. Our gross margin for Q4 was 81.3%, which is down compared to 82.1% in Q4 of '13, reflecting the higher level of tech resale and third-party services compared to the year-ago period.
Full year gross margin of 82.2% was basically flat to 2013.
Looking at operating spending. The fourth quarter operating expenses before share-based compensation expense and acquisition-related adjustments were $524 million, which is up 17% compared to adjusted Q4 of '13 operating expenses, which also excluded a settlement charge.
For the full year, operating expenses before share-based compensation expense and acquisition-related adjustments up 18% to $1.96 billion. Adjusting the growth rate for the extra week reduces the Q4 growth rate to approximately 10% and the full year growth rate to about 16%.
Client service expenses increased 17% compared to Q4 of '13 and 19% for the full year, driven primarily by continued increase in revenue-generating associates and our services business.
Our investment and software development was up 15% compared to Q4 of '13 and up 16% for the full year, it continues to be driven by investments in our growth initiatives.
G&A expense increased 16% compared to Q4 of '13 and 13% for the full year, driven mostly by increases in personnel expense related to our strong growth and higher amortization expense related to recent acquisitions and acquired intangibles.
Moving to operating margins. Our operating margin before share-based compensation expense and acquisition-related adjustments was 24.7% in Q4. This is down 90 basis points compared to Q4 of '13 due to higher tech resale and deferred third-party services. We were also impacted by the extra week, which ended up having a slightly bigger impact on expenses than it did on some revenue elements, such as professional services incurred a full week of expenses but had low utilization due to the holiday.
As we indicated last quarter, we expect the first year of incorporating Siemens health systems into our results to bring our adjusted operating margins down to the low 20% range. We expect operating margin to return to the mid-20s by 2017 based on ongoing leverage in our core business and as you expected accretion ramps.
Moving to net earnings and EPS. Our GAAP net earnings in Q4 were $148 million or $0.42 per diluted share. GAAP net earnings include share-based compensation expense, which had a net impact on earnings of $11 million or $0.03 per diluted share. GAAP net earnings also include adjustments related to our acquisition of Siemens Health Services which had a net impact on earnings of $4 million or $0.02 per diluted share.
Adjusted net earnings were $163 million, and adjusted EPS was $0.47, which is up 20% compared to Q4 of '13. For the year, adjusted net earnings were $576 million and adjusted EPS was $1.65, which is up 17% from 2013.
The Q4 tax rate for adjusted net earnings was 30%, which is lower than our normal tax rate primarily due to reinstatement of the R&D tax credit during the quarter. In total, the lower tax rate benefited Q4 adjusted EPS by $0.02, it was about $0.01 tied to a prior period portion of the credit.
For 2015, we expect our tax rate to be in the 33% to 35% range.
Now move to our balance sheet. We ended Q4 with $1.65 billion of total cash and investments, which is up $94 million compared to Q3. Our total debt, including capital lease obligations, is $130 million, down from $147 million in Q3. It was previously announced, we added $500 million of debt early this year, which will increase our balance sheet efficiency and provide ample financial flexibility lower cost. Impact on earnings from the debt be minimal, has not changed our guidance.
Total receivables ended the quarter with $673 million, which is up $56 million from Q3 driven by strong sales in the quarter.
Our DSO in Q4 was 66 days, which compares to DSO of 67 days in Q3 and 67 days in the year-ago quarter. 
Operating cash flow for the quarter was $223 million. Q4 capital expenditures were $76 million and capitalized software was $47 million.
Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow less capital expenditures and capitalized software, were $100 million for the quarter.
For the full year, operating cash flow increased 22% to $847 million. Free cash flow for the year was $393 million, with capital expenditures of $276 million and capitalized software of $178 million.
Moving to capitalized software. $47 million of capitalized software in Q4 represents 37% of $126 million of total investment in development opportunities.
Software amortization for the quarter was $28 million, resulting in net capitalization of $19 million or 15% of our total R&D investment.
2015  we expect to continue generating good free cash flow with strong expected operating cash flow growth offsetting an expected increase in capital expenditures tied to beginning construction of a new campus and capital expenditures related to our Siemens Health Services acquisition.
Now I would like to provide an update on our acquisition of Siemens Health Services, which closed last week as scheduled. Purchase price was $1.37 billion, which includes the $1.3 billion agreed upon price and $70 million in working capital adjustments. a significant amount of integration and transition preparation in the 6 months since we announced the acquisition. We still have a lot of work to do, but all of our work today has supported our positive view of health services and we are very excited to move forward as a combined company.
Now I'll go through Q1 and full year 2015 guidance. For Q1, we expect revenue between $1.05 billion and $1.1 billion, with the midpoint reflecting growth of 37% over Q1 of '14.
For the full year, we expect revenue between $4.8 billion and $5 billion, reflecting 44% growth at the midpoint.
We expect Q1 adjusted EPS before share-based compensation and acquisition-related adjustments to be $0.44 to $0.45 per share, with the midpoint reflecting 20% growth over Q1 '14 adjusted EPS. I'd like to point out that the consensus for Q1 adjusted EPS increased from $0.44 to $0.46 in the last 30 days, to include some significant outliers. Our guidance is based on our outlook, not consensus, but I want to point this out because Q1 consensus tend to shift a bit out of line with the rest of the year, especially when you consider Q1 will naturally conclude the least amount of accretion from health services.
For the full year, we continue to expect adjusted EPS before share-based compensation and acquisition-related adjustments to be $2.05 to $2.15, with the midpoint reflecting 27% growth. We estimate for the impact of share-based compensation expense is approximately $0.03 to $0.04 in Q1 and $0.14 to $0.16 for the full year.
Moving to bookings guidance, we expect bookings revenue in Q1 of $1.05 billion to $1.15 billion, with the midpoint reflecting 21% growth over Q1 of '14.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Zane.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations.I'll start with our results. Our bookings revenue in Q4 of $1.16 billion reflects 5% growth over Q4 2013, which is an all-time high. F
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations.
I'll start with our results. Our bookings revenue in Q4 of $1.16 billion reflects 5% growth over Q4 2013, which is an all-time high. Full year booking of $4.25 billion represents 13% over 2013. IVR bookings performance was very good, especially when you consider the mix of long-term bookings of lower than it has been in the past. In Q4, long-term bookings were 24% of total bookings. This is well below our typical of 30% to 32% range. And we did have 1 ITWorks deal in the quarter, the overall lower mix of long-term contracts is a primary reason our bookings were at the lower end of our guidance range.
For the year, 30% of our contracts are long-term compared to 32% last year. As Mike will discuss, our outlook for ITWorks is very good.
Looking at overall contract size. We had strong level of contracts over $5 million and $10 million, with 33 contracts over $5 million, including 16 over $10 million. For the year, we had record levels of contracts in both categories with 112 contracts over $5 million and 63 over $10 million. New business activity was good, with 28% of our bookings coming from outside of our core Millennium install base for both the quarter and full year. This is slightly lower percent than last year which is more reflective of success in our base and lack of success outside of our base.
Looking ahead, our pipeline reflects more business opportunities that we have ever had going into a year with a notable step up problem a number of opportunities we saw in 2014. I'm also pleased with how well-positioned we are competitively in these opportunities. The result I expect 2015 to be a very good year for new business.
I believe we still have a multiyear period ahead of us, where there would be opportunities to win new footprints where the core EHR is Cerner's. Overlapping this opportunity is growing demand for Population Health solutions which continues to be fueled by trend away from fee-for-service payment models. The recent examples of this trend is HHS announcement last month they intend intent to shift from fee-for-service to value-based reimbursement more rapidly than many people expected, with the goal of having 90% of Medicare payments tied to quality or value by 2018.
I believe these trends play to Cerner strengths, as we improve our solutions that meet the present need of healthcare providers, we're also widening our differentiation in Population Health, interoperability and having the most open EHR.
Now I'll discuss a few key areas of our business, starting with Population Health. Our Population Health organization had a strong 2014, with revenue increasing more than 20% to $450 million. This was driven by sales of Enterprise Data Warehouse, analytics, clinical process optimization, HIE, Patient Portal and Healthe registries.
2014 was also a year in which we demonstrated that our Healthe Intent platform has great potential beyond our install base by establishing important new Population Health footprints outside our base. We have many more prospects in 2015. As I mentioned last quarter, we believe we will have instances where our Population Health capabilities are sold first and then lead to new EHR footprints.
Another trend that emerged in 2014 is we're already starting to see opportunities to displace niche providers of Population Health solutions that were purchased by our clients as recently as 18 to 24 months ago. One of our largest bookings in Q4 was for replacing several niche Population Health solutions at a large client. The niche providers have not taken on the significant challenges of aggregating normalizing clinical claims, the financial data across multiple systems. It is also difficult for them to match our ability to bring near real-time information into the clinicians work flow. As a result, we believe most competing offerings are using incomplete latent data sets, part of workflow which makes this level at less attractive to providers.
Moving to our Revenue Cycle business. We had a very good year that included strong growth and good progress of bringing key clients live on our Revenue Cycle solutions. For the year, our Revenue Cycle business grew more than 30% to approximately $200 million, which is a fivefold increase since 2010, reflecting our strong progress on returns on the significant ongoing R&D investments we made making in this space.
A key for our Revenue Cycle business has been getting more large clients to roll out our Revenue Cycle solutions. 2014 was a big year in this regard as we brought sites live for some of our largest clients. And our hosting reference sites us. This success contributed to another 1 of our large IDN clients purchasing a broad suite of Revenue Cycle solutions in the fourth quarter to implement across their 12 acute facilities and 85 ambulatory clinics. 
In addition to our strong current capabilities contributing to this election, a key factor was our work on next-generation Revenue Cycle solutions designed to support emerging financial models that are more aligned with Population Health.
Looking ahead, we have a very strong pipeline for Revenue Cycle that includes several of our large IDN clients. We also believe the significant experience the health services associates bring will help continue our strong momentum.
Moving to the ambulatory space, where we had a strong Q4 and year that included the following highlights: 16% revenue growth to $151 million, record bookings including 30% growth in the business office services where we continue to gain momentum, signed 11 signature displacements of our key competitors, including the 3 largest clients of 1 competitor; signed an alignment deal with an investor-owned postacute care company to do outsource billing for their providers in several markets; and we received best-in-class recognition in the 1 to 10 physician ambulatory EMR category.
We also had a great year in the small hospital market, adding more than 20 CommunityWorks clients during the year and growing bookings over 50%. we're also recognizing it by classes of category leader in the community hospital market.
Outside of the U.S. we had a very strong Q4, with revenue growth growing 34% driven by strength in the U.K., Middle East and Australia. This growth, combined with a good growth in Q3, offsets decline in the first half of the year and led to 6% full year growth. We remain well positioned for good 2015 based on the strong Global pipeline, great 2014 bookings and the complementary Global business the human health services.
I'd like to highlight an announcement from early this year that we helped the UAE Ministry of Health become the first organization in the Middle East to roll out a number portal. The online portal is a bilingual website that allows residents of Dubai and Northern Emirates to connect to communicate directly with the Ministry's healthcare providers. As we discussed in the past, population health is very much a Global opportunity and this is nice milestone and an important region that could lead to broader Population Health opportunities.
One additional Global highlight is that Cerner client Marina became the first U.S. the first non-U.S. hospital during the HIMSS enterprises award. The award recipients are HIMSS stage 6 and 7 organizations that demonstrate significant sustainable improvement of patient outcomes through the utilization of EHRs and information technology, while achieving return on investment.
Before turning the call over to Mike, I'd like to make a few comments on our recently closed acquisition of Siemens Health Services. We're very pleased to welcome the Health Services associates and clients to Cerner. a significant amount of pre-close efforts on both sides, we have hit the ground running. We just had our first joint forecast meeting this past week, just 2 days after the official close of the acquisition. These meetings reinforce my positive view about the opportunities we have as a combined organization. We have a good initial view of cross-sell opportunities and we are already in discussions with many of our new clients about providing additional Cerner solutions to meet their needs, really from replacing their EHR to adding Population Health or device connectivity capabilities. We look forward to providing you updates as we progress through the year.
With that, turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: .Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks, professional services and provide a client success highlight.I'll start with ITWorks, which had a great year including a new contract in the fourth quarter. Our new ITWorks
componenttext:
.
Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks, professional services and provide a client success highlight.
I'll start with ITWorks, which had a great year including a new contract in the fourth quarter. Our new ITWorks client is Genesis Health System, based in Davenport, Iowa. Like most organizations, they have been on a journey to increase quality while reducing costs. They've been an ITWorks alignment is a good match, can improve service and allow for predictable IT spend.
The new relationship also calls for the establishment of a value alignment office, which is aimed at helping Genesis innovate and optimize care processes, ensure patients receive the best possible care, increase return on technology investments. The agreement also includes new services such as help desk operations, application services, the optimization of IT service delivery across the health system.
Financial results for ITWorks were excellent in 2014, with revenue growing over 60% to more than $300 million. We believe our offering is very compelling, because we help clients control spending while getting more done and achieving a higher level of value. The ITWorks clients are all referenceable, 100% have test Meaningful Use, 74% are at HIMSS EMR adoption level 6 or 7, which is more than 3x the 22% industry attainment level. Overall, ITWorks clients are typically mono class that's stay on their latest code, embrace new solutions and services and are strong Cerner advocates. We believe that as provider organizations face ongoing pressures, our ITWorks value proposition will continue to resonate very well. This is reflected in a very strong pipeline, and we expect 2015 to be a record year.
Now I'd like to provide some highlights on from a strong year from a professional services organization that they delivered. In 2014, our professional services revenue grew more than 25% and eclipsed the $1 billion mark, strong growth in traditional implementation revenue as well as operational management, performance improvement and other nonimplementation revenue that is creating diversity in our services business. With approximately 6,000 associates, our professional services organization is the largest healthcare IT-focused consulting business in the world. I believe our services' capabilities create a competitive advantage for competitors that rely almost entirely on third-party service because of our ability to deliver a predictable outcome at a predictable cost.
In 2014, we continued to advance our implementation methodologies, including our model system approach that starts with a fully built best practices system that allows for fine-tuning as users get hands-on experience and training. This approach has the potential to significantly reduce implementation duration and effort, which should benefit new clients transitioning to the Cerner platform.
In 2015, we are focused on first facilitating seamless migration for clients lines of health services that choose to move to Cerner; second, continuing to grow nonimplementation components of our business such as process optimization, Enterprise Resource Planning and performance improvement; and third, staffing expected increase in new footprints that Zane discussed earlier.
Now I'd like to briefly highlight a client accomplishment involving success with our Revenue Cycle solutions. Recently, Cerner client Lafayette General Hospital received a MAP award for the -- from the Healthcare Financial Management Association. MAP stands for Measure, Apply and Perform, and Lafayette General is 1 of only 3 organizations in the country recognized by HFMA for performance improvement and Revenue Cycle. Key achievement of Lafayette was decreasing net AR days from 75 days to 44 days. They were also able to reduce their levels of discharge not funnel build from nearly $20 million down to approximately $6 million. A key to their success has been their ability to leverage Cerner's clinically driven Revenue Cycle to enable staff to capture accurate and complete information at the front end, provide financial clearing capabilities and enable client data to drive coding, billing and cash collection operations.
With that, I'll turn the call over for questions.

componenttext: So you always had a very strong year going into your base in terms of bookings you've generated. As you think about 2015, think of the priorities for pursuing new business. Obviously, Zane I heard you talked about incredibly strong pipeline. How much you think about that and segment the opportunities of the pipeline at least qualitatively in terms of going into the existing base of your own customers, go first going through existing base, now the Siemens customers that you have on where I assume there's a pretty nice very hopefully early to achieve increment of sell opportunity versus the replacement market which seems to continue to be shaping at least in the nice way in your direction?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015

componenttext: This is Marc. I think the overall market as we look for '15, I think you segmented it pretty well, Michael. Our base kind of the HS base and then the new opportunities. Zane has spent a lot of time working on our new opportunities and the new business space, particularly the large regional player is very active in the marketplace and I think you would see we provide we do some segmentation to match up with the buyers, you think about our CommunityWorks offering on the smaller end, regional community hospital marketplace, the IDN segment and then the investor owned segment. And so we for further segmentation down that and there's also outside the U.S. organizations which each country reflects a different marketplace as we look at those. And so we look at -- we attack those in different ways and with frankly across the board do we see good opportunities across all segments of both new business as well as our install base, and that's across the U.S. and outside the U.S.

componenttext: From a Siemens perspective, I spent fair amount of time on the number of our clients and clients are very receptive and excited that Cerner has stepped in, in to acquire health services and I think there's many that will -- that are looking for a strong path moving forward with Cerner and whether that's on the platform or whether that's perhaps on Millennium and each client's journey is different, but I've been very pleased with how the clients have responded to this date.

componenttext: I just look at say there's a lot more opportunity in 2015 than what we saw in 2014 in total, particularly on the new business side, but we see a number of opportunities that Mike pointed out in his comments around ITWorks side. We'll continue to be judicious about how we engage in the Rev Cycle phase. And so I think you're going to see a little -- it's not a natural to see some lumpiness in terms of how those longer-term bookings will pull through and have an impact on those numbers. So I don't think there's any trend per se in that space other than we feel very good about the ITWorks activity in the pipeline and how that may be impacting the bookings outlook as we move forward.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Really as we've given the fact that Q1 is going to have maybe a partial impact of Health Cerner health services that and after going through a forecast meeting there which actually I have a little bit color that was really impressive that both their teams
componenttext: Really as we've given the fact that Q1 is going to have maybe a partial impact of Health Cerner health services that and after going through a forecast meeting there which actually I have a little bit color that was really impressive that both their teams and our teams were able to have a pretty decent forecast format and as I've on do their opportunities, they're not going to have much contribution to bookings in the first quarter. I mean, they're kind of waiting for the close. Clients are certainly looking to see what the next step is and those conversations are ongoing. But most of the activity that you're going to see driven by in Q1 from a bookings perspective will be coming almost entirely from Cerner. I think as you look at the Revenue side, top line side, kind of can look at health services providing us between $95 million and $100 million a month on the revenue top line. So I think that's pretty good estimate, that's kind of the number we've talked about and I think that's one that our most recent work with continue to confirm. I think from that perspective, you're going to get a good view of the company for those of you are looking kind of get a little bit of historical view at least kind of the prior year when under Siemens, their 9-30 financial statements under GAAP will be issued some time in the next 60 days as one of our filings, and it will break out health services. So you'll get a little bit of a view. I'll just indicate that when you look at those numbers, top line and I think on the earnings line, they had some onetime things as they put together their GAAP statements and operations that moved up their earnings a little bit more than you'd expect. Basically, if you exclude those in their earnings would have been breakeven, which is kind of what we talked about. So that's a little kind of the color I can provide right now as far as what their impact on Q1 is going to be. And obviously, once we get them in our income statement format and have a little bit better view, we'll certainly think probably be looking to update our trend file and do different things in that space as we combine the companies, there's things like backlog that we just have different approaches on certain elements and try to parse them out between contract and support may not make sense going forward. We may have to go to a single backlog number. But our goal always is to be transparent and provide you guys what you need to make your decisions.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015

componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Steve Halper with FBR.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the cash flow comments that you forecasted or may could you provide a little bit more color I mean Marc just because we're not really from familiar with the levels of capital requirements at Siemens or what you're planning on doing on a
componenttext: Just going back to the cash flow comments that you forecasted or may could you provide a little bit more color I mean Marc just because we're not really from familiar with the levels of capital requirements at Siemens or what you're planning on doing on an R&D basis. Are you looking at flat free cash flow in 2015?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Marc. When you're looking at 2015, right now my best estimate is that we'd expect it to be right around $400 million. So basically flat to this year. The primary driver of that is going to be more CapEx. The CapEx required for health services isn'
componenttext: This is Marc. When you're looking at 2015, right now my best estimate is that we'd expect it to be right around $400 million. So basically flat to this year. The primary driver of that is going to be more CapEx. The CapEx required for health services isn't significant. There are some things we want to invest in. Clearly, just their offices and making sure that they got what they need, a little bit near relative to their data center, getting that up to speed relative to our standards and be able to utilize some of that space. But I think overall, even with those additions and even with spending more money on our campus than we certainly did last year, we should still be able to fund all of that and still drive out right around $400 million of free cash flow.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: And would you expect that number to your level of CapEx, does that stay elevated for a number of years? Or is '15 a little bit of an increase because of the campus buildout?
componenttext: And would you expect that number to your level of CapEx, does that stay elevated for a number of years? Or is '15 a little bit of an increase because of the campus buildout?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: The campus build out is going to be the key for '15 and '16. So that impact those years. Once we get the first phase of that campus done, we'll likely be able to take a little bit of a pause. Once again dependent on the group because the key for us is tha
componenttext: The campus build out is going to be the key for '15 and '16. So that impact those years. Once we get the first phase of that campus done, we'll likely be able to take a little bit of a pause. Once again dependent on the group because the key for us is that we are a growth company and we've got places to go, put our people and make them productive. So but I think right now that's kind of looking like a '15 and '16 impact, with '17 probably being relieved from some of those debt spend.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Bob Jones with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Bob Jones with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Marc, I actually want to ask one on operating margins. I know the target coming into 4Q I think was from more than 50 basis points of expansion. You obviously didn't see that. Margins were actually down. And then also for the year I think you came in belo
componenttext: Marc, I actually want to ask one on operating margins. I know the target coming into 4Q I think was from more than 50 basis points of expansion. You obviously didn't see that. Margins were actually down. And then also for the year I think you came in below the annual target as well. I understand you guys are talking about holiday week being unproductive, but I'd imagine some of that is more of an annual issue. So I guess as you think about the margin progression you saw in '14, could you maybe just and the quarter for that matter, could you maybe just talk a little bit about kind of what went off target as far as the things you thought you had control of?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the key talking about the holiday week is not so much of that it's a holiday because Christmas comes over year as my kids think of those, and am I right. The fact that we have -- we do a 52-, 53-week year, so this year was a 14-week quarter which
componenttext: I think the key talking about the holiday week is not so much of that it's a holiday because Christmas comes over year as my kids think of those, and am I right. The fact that we have -- we do a 52-, 53-week year, so this year was a 14-week quarter which include that extra week which had more -- had the normal spend, spend but didn't have as much top line impact. I think when you look, we've always looked at the company as we should have a goal of driving down 100 bps per year growth in our margins and our operating margins. I think and that growth is going to kind of go up and down on an annual basis. But if you look back to 2010 and the last 4 years, we're probably averaged right at 100 basis points a year of growth. I think the key really for our operating margins at this point is looking at '15 because when we add in the health services rather and their much lower margins from those revenues, you're going to see a significant impact on our operating margins. As I said in my comments, we'd expect those to be down kind of in the low 20s from current 25 potentially plus percent levels. The good news is that as the accretion starts driving out as we go into the out years, that quickly gets back to current levels and begins to be able to go up at 100 basis points a year expected growth rate. So the 2014 strong, and Q4 particularly, really the margin impact was much driven by a strong hardware quarter and device resale quarter as anything. But I think it doesn't change our view of the business and the opportunities we have to get more efficiencies out. And clearly, as we add health services, bigger company, we should have more opportunities for those efficiencies.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. And then I guess maybe Zane, just 1 on the new business I mean nice suite with period in health particularly given that it's outside of your EMR base. Any sense you can give us on what the bookings or annual revenue contribution is for s
componenttext: That makes sense. And then I guess maybe Zane, just 1 on the new business I mean nice suite with period in health particularly given that it's outside of your EMR base. Any sense you can give us on what the bookings or annual revenue contribution is for strategic deal like this and maybe more broadly anything on the pipeline around similar deals that are focused around Healthe Intent?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: As we mentioned, the Population Health is about $450 million in revenue, and we had the good growth and we are anticipating continued good growth in that space so that you can kind of use that as a marker for how you can anticipate our Population Health b
componenttext: As we mentioned, the Population Health is about $450 million in revenue, and we had the good growth and we are anticipating continued good growth in that space so that you can kind of use that as a marker for how you can anticipate our Population Health business to grow in some of those kinds of semantics that I can't speak about the individual deal economics.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of David Windley from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of David Windley from Jefferies.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as you think about the Siemens side of your bookings for the full year, I know, Marc, you already said first quarter won't be much of a contribution. As you think about the full year, can you help us understand which of the major buckets you expect to
componenttext: So as you think about the Siemens side of your bookings for the full year, I know, Marc, you already said first quarter won't be much of a contribution. As you think about the full year, can you help us understand which of the major buckets you expect to see the most traction in the early going? Is it selling Millennium into the base? Is it Population Health leading? Zane, as you kind of talk about going to market Population Health first and following with EHR? Or is it even managed services? Can you help us understand where that traction will come early.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. I think you'll see the traction I think in managed services will continue to be a strong element for that's kind of an existing business for them and one that will continue. We offer some additional services in that space. So it's really --
componenttext: This is Zane. I think you'll see the traction I think in managed services will continue to be a strong element for that's kind of an existing business for them and one that will continue. We offer some additional services in that space. So it's really -- remember our first objective is to make sure that we keep that client base satisfied. And moving forward I think you will see a number of clients that may think about moving to a Millennium platform, and so there may be some benefits in that, so that it will be reflected in our guidance as well. But it's a blend of the Managed Services, which is what they continue to do, some add-on solutions. We'll continue to sell Soarian financial in a patient accounting on a stand-alone basis. There's a marketplace for standalone patient accounting, particularly given one of our competitors has announced of sunsetting some of their applications in the larger space. So I think you'll see a number of different buckets that falls and they're all kind of reflective in the bookings guidance that we provided.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Marc to your point on margin going down first and then working its way back up over time, are there say significant buckets of expense that you could identify to us that will be -- that will come out of the Siemens side that will be the con
componenttext: Okay. And then Marc to your point on margin going down first and then working its way back up over time, are there say significant buckets of expense that you could identify to us that will be -- that will come out of the Siemens side that will be the contributors to that synergy and margin accretion over the next couple of years? And are those things tied to the pace at which say old Siemens base converts over to new Cerner footprint base?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Relative to I mean the synergies are not -- synergies are certainly important. I think the efficiencies come from just the combination of our 2 organizations. I don't know I mean we like the health services associates. We think they are talented, the
componenttext: Yes. Relative to I mean the synergies are not -- synergies are certainly important. I think the efficiencies come from just the combination of our 2 organizations. I don't know I mean we like the health services associates. We think they are talented, they're experienced, they're valuable assets. So we're pleased to keep the work with them and to build their momentum certainly within that client base and our shared client base. So I think a lot of the synergies are just their efficiencies relative to being a organization under a large corporate parent that has a certain method of operating that is somewhat more bureaucratic than perhaps Cerner Corporation is. There are things that we just see from how you operate. And certainly, there are elements of staffing that we can repurpose people to be focused on revenue-producing activities rather than industry-type activities. So we think there are opportunities to go drive that out. And given the targets we set, getting to $175 million of OE kind of coming from these assets by 2017, we think those are eminently attainable and if we just keep executing, keep driving our business and getting with their client base and driving them forward that we should be able to deliver that without great deal of effort.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015

componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Lisa Gill with JPMorgan.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Gavin Weiss in for Lisa. Zane, I wanted to touch on your comments on the ambulatory space. I think you said you had 11 displacements including 3 from 2 of the largest clients from 1 competitor. I just wanted to get some more color on the
componenttext: This is actually Gavin Weiss in for Lisa. Zane, I wanted to touch on your comments on the ambulatory space. I think you said you had 11 displacements including 3 from 2 of the largest clients from 1 competitor. I just wanted to get some more color on the drivers of those displacements? Is it just fast with the product or the providers now affiliated with a core Cerner institution?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: These are long-standing clients of Cerner's on the acute perspective that have and I'd say it's kind of a combination of factors, one, our ambulatory solution is incredibly good and the investments that we've made in the R&D and the improvements that have
componenttext: These are long-standing clients of Cerner's on the acute perspective that have and I'd say it's kind of a combination of factors, one, our ambulatory solution is incredibly good and the investments that we've made in the R&D and the improvements that have been made on the ambulatory side, our clients have seen. And as they move towards further clinical integration and wanting to create more system, if you will, they are looking to have an integrated -- they're looking for an integrated acute and ambulatory solution as they move forward. And I think you'll also look at organization and say that, that competitor was also not providing the kind of value that those clients were looking for. So it's kind of a combination of factors that comes together, but incredibly long good wins for us this year and representative of a trend that we think we'll continue to see.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015

componenttext: They will impact earnings, but, as you've likely noted, our guidance basically remains the same since we talked about it at the end of Q3. So it's -- we'll just cover that interest expense within our existing guidance.

componenttext: Zane, you made an interesting comment about 2015 and I think you indicated that the pipeline, I mean activity for '15 was actually greater than 2014. headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: I am speaking about hospitals, primarily, so in the hospital marketplace and it's across many segments. So and it's as we've talked about for a while, this is a replacement market, not a meaningful, a replacement market that's preparing for changes, that
componenttext: I am speaking about hospitals, primarily, so in the hospital marketplace and it's across many segments. So and it's as we've talked about for a while, this is a replacement market, not a meaningful, a replacement market that's preparing for changes, that business model that's preparing for changes in being true systems and just not seeing the value from their existing suppliers that they need on a going forward basis. And it's much stronger than it was in 2014, and we see the level of activity significantly up.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then would you say a good portion of that is coming from Siemens? And then would there be maybe 1 or 2 other vendors that maybe on the horizon or Meditech that you'd highlight? Or is it really maybe 10% Siemens? Just any more details would be gr
componenttext: Okay. And then would you say a good portion of that is coming from Siemens? And then would there be maybe 1 or 2 other vendors that maybe on the horizon or Meditech that you'd highlight? Or is it really maybe 10% Siemens? Just any more details would be great.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So obviously, one of those you mentioned has announced some sunsetting solutions. And that's creating part of that which actually I would say additive to even the level of activity that we've seen. If Siemens activity is actually additive to the vol
componenttext: Sure. So obviously, one of those you mentioned has announced some sunsetting solutions. And that's creating part of that which actually I would say additive to even the level of activity that we've seen. If Siemens activity is actually additive to the volume that we were seeing early on. So we are already seeing increased levels of activity for '15 and some of these other events including some that we've created through our own acquisition is driving even more demand for our solutions. So it is all those factors out there, but the activity level is just is higher than it was in '14 by orders magnitude.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Sean Wieland, Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Sean Wieland, Piper Jaffray.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if you could break down for us, if I'm a Millennium customer, what's on my shopping list that I really have to buy to be ready for Medicare shift to fee for value? Put in another way, what are some of the specific capabilities that you're bringing to t
componenttext: So if you could break down for us, if I'm a Millennium customer, what's on my shopping list that I really have to buy to be ready for Medicare shift to fee for value? Put in another way, what are some of the specific capabilities that you're bringing to the table there that you think are unique to you?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Zane. So Sean, there's a couple of things, which you'd first think about. We have what we call our Lighthouse offerings, which are truly around how do you provide the best quality care at a lower cost. And so we are able to actually the cont
componenttext: Sure. This is Zane. So Sean, there's a couple of things, which you'd first think about. We have what we call our Lighthouse offerings, which are truly around how do you provide the best quality care at a lower cost. And so we are able to actually the content and process through our software and solutions to help drive better outcomes both from a patient perspective and a financial perspective. So the first thing you want to do is go future proof yourself around some of those quality metrics and prepare for that. As you take more risk, our Population Health offerings will be the next set of things that you'll want to have and you have to have in this marketplace. So the registries, the access to data, so you're going to have to be able to think about your data in different ways and he who has the data wins in the future game. And following that data is going to be really incredibly important, so having an open interoperable solution is a very important element. So you're going to need an EMR that's capable of actually accepting different solutions, getting it back into the clinicians workflow, get actually you're going to need all of Cerner to be successful moving forward. And the things that we have built and the things that we will build will continue to add value. So it's a very exciting time. More risk that's borne obviously has impact on the our clients, but we view that as very positive from an IT perspective and their need for to understand the data, know the data and to impact at the Point of Care is going to be more important. So you really think about all those components as part of that future proof.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: How about specifically some of the stuff Intermountain Healthcare? Or should I wait for HIMMS for that?
componenttext: How about specifically some of the stuff Intermountain Healthcare? Or should I wait for HIMMS for that?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll give you the as an update around HIMMS for that. But we're very pleased with the progress that's been made in Intermountain. We anticipate going live here in the first quarter. And so I think you'll get an opportunity to speak with both our client a
componenttext: We'll give you the as an update around HIMMS for that. But we're very pleased with the progress that's been made in Intermountain. We anticipate going live here in the first quarter. And so I think you'll get an opportunity to speak with both our client and Jeff as it relates to what's happening at Intermountain, and we believe that represents another turn of the crank on an EHR that will be ready for the future, so there are a number of things that we're pretty excited about.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015

componenttext: Next question is from the line of Mohan Naidu with Stephens.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: My questions, Marc, maybe on the bookings. So you noted about the long-term contracts. What do you construe long-term contracts? I presume ITWorks, RevWorks. What else?
componenttext: My questions, Marc, maybe on the bookings. So you noted about the long-term contracts. What do you construe long-term contracts? I presume ITWorks, RevWorks. What else?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Usually anything that's got a duration that's going to be 5-plus years. So ITWorks tend to be 7 to 10 years. RevWorks are somewhere to that. So that's how we would -- Managed Services or hosting agreements. All of those, and keep in mind, when we sign a b
componenttext: Usually anything that's got a duration that's going to be 5-plus years. So ITWorks tend to be 7 to 10 years. RevWorks are somewhere to that. So that's how we would -- Managed Services or hosting agreements. All of those, and keep in mind, when we sign a brand-new client and they buy software and services and implementation, many of those also buy Managed Services or hosting services. So that contract component of it will be a long-term booking and the others will -- the rest of it will be just kind of normal.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one follow-up question on the Siemens contribution you noted $95 million to $100 million per month. Is it fair to say that majority of that is going to be support and maintenance revenue?
componenttext: Okay. And one follow-up question on the Siemens contribution you noted $95 million to $100 million per month. Is it fair to say that majority of that is going to be support and maintenance revenue?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The majority of it will be in backlog for health services that will come into the income statement. The classification of it will vary, but it is flowing from long-term contracts that will have a variety of components to the revenue, but it's basical
componenttext: Yes. The majority of it will be in backlog for health services that will come into the income statement. The classification of it will vary, but it is flowing from long-term contracts that will have a variety of components to the revenue, but it's basically a single bucket of dollars that will be parsed out in different places. But it's coming out of primarily the backlog.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Steven Valiquette with UBS.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015

componenttext: So one of your smaller hospital EHR competitors reported some soft earnings about a week or 2 ago. And they talked about this Meaningful Use at that station period for FY '15 being increased from 90 days to 365 days starting back in October of last year. caught some hospitals unprepared to start a year long attestation and maybe a push out some purchase related to Stage 2. So I guess I'm just curious if you think that the CMS timing situation maybe had any impact on your bookings in that just reported 4Q '14 and also could that impact the current 1Q '15 as well?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. I don't see -- we've been talking about this for a while that Meaningful Use has not been part of our bookings elements. And our clients had been past that dialogue for quite some time as it relates to impact on our bookings or revenues. And
componenttext: This is Zane. I don't see -- we've been talking about this for a while that Meaningful Use has not been part of our bookings elements. And our clients had been past that dialogue for quite some time as it relates to impact on our bookings or revenues. And we've been in a different marketplace around the replacement side of that. So I don't anticipate that had future impact and I don't think it had any impact on the previous quarter either.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015

componenttext: This is Marc. Most of even the new business opportunities outside of client base are people probably together something to meet Stage 2.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll say actually say substantially all of them have strategies for Meaningful Use. They're making -- they're looking increased level of activity is not a Meaningful Use conversation. It is about how do I create a platform for the future in which I can
componenttext: So I'll say actually say substantially all of them have strategies for Meaningful Use. They're making -- they're looking increased level of activity is not a Meaningful Use conversation. It is about how do I create a platform for the future in which I can think about either remaining a viable standalone organization or creating scale to be a bigger larger organization or preparing for changes in payment models, aligning across the continuum of care, all of which plays into Cerner's strengths.

componenttext: Jamie, I don't know that really historically it's going to have a lot of value. I think as you look going forward, they're going to have the same book-to-bill level, we won't know, I don't expect that. At this point, I don't know that I can given that in Q1 which is the bookings number we can really talk about, it's going to be so low that it's not really worth doing the math to have their book-to-bill. We should be able to give you a more better sense of what their bookings level is going to be as we go forward and get a better sense of kind of what we think on a quarterly basis, they'll be able to do, is it 1 to 1 or is it 0.5 to 1? Is it -- I can't tell you today what that is, but I can tell you it's going to be lower than ours.

componenttext: Okay. That's great. And then Jamie, maybe real quick, you mentioned that there were some guys that were already at risk of being replaced and I assume some of your core clients. headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's good question, Jamie. I'll speak first to kind of what I think has happened in the replacement activity. I think the replacement activity has been driven by people that early on they had something that sounded like it was pop health related and are c
componenttext: It's good question, Jamie. I'll speak first to kind of what I think has happened in the replacement activity. I think the replacement activity has been driven by people that early on they had something that sounded like it was pop health related and are clients in the industry was needing anything and grasping at some of those niche providers that had something of some value. But at the end of the day, it's not a comprehensive platform for managing Population Health, and I think what the future is that a true platform based Population Health strategy, and I've talked before about kind of 1.0 buyers in this space versus 2.0 buyers and what I mean by that, people that have actually been assumed taking risk, need for a system-based approach that's an enterprisewide-based approach that thinks across the continuum side of this. As it relates to integrated services, I think there are some compelling offerings. I think there'd be some -- I think you'll see additional solutions and services for companies that do provide both technology and service moving forward. And I think you'll continue to see business models evolve as we get further into the Population Health and the more risks that our clients take on, I do think there some opportunity for that side.
