headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Cerner Corporation's First Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Today's date is May 7, 2015, and this call is being recorded. The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forwar
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Cerner Corporation's First Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Today's date is May 7, 2015, and this call is being recorded. The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, including, without limitation, those regarding projections of future revenues or earnings, operating margins, operating expenses, product development, new markets or prospects for the company solutions and plans and expectations related to the acquisition and integration of Siemens Health Service Business. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by the forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements may be found on the Item 1A in Cerner Form 10-K, together with the company's other filings.
A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed in this earnings call can be found in the company's earnings release, which was furnished to the SEC today and posted on the Investors section of cerner.com.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Marc Naughton, Chief Financial Officer of Cerner Corporation.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call. I'll lead off today with the review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with the results highlights and marketplace observations. Mike Nill, Executive Vice Presiden
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call. I'll lead off today with the review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with the results highlights and marketplace observations. Mike Nill, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, will discuss operations. Neal Patterson, our Chairman and CEO, will join us for Q&A. Now I will turn to our results.
Overall, while revenue was below our expectations, we had a solid quarter, highlighted by very strong bookings, and our outlook remains positive. Our bookings revenue in Q1 was $1.2 billion. This is an all-time high and reflects 32% growth over Q1 of '14, driven by strong growth in traditional Cerner bookings, with minimal bookings contribution from Health Services.
The revenue backlog ended the quarter at $13 billion, which is up from $9.2 billion a year ago, and reflects the strong bookings in Q1 and the inclusion of backlog from Health Services.
Revenue in the quarter was $996 million, which is up 27% over Q1 of '14. Total revenue for Cerner was approximately $820 million, with the remaining $176 million attributable to Health Services. The total is approximately $50 million below our guidance range, with the shortfall roughly equally split between Cerner and Health Services. On the Cerner side, the higher percentage of the record bookings that came from long-term contracts and the lower percentage divided the generated in-quarter revenue. Additionally, services in reimbursed travel was lower-than-expected. On the Health Services side, part of the shortfall was due to the $12.5 million adjustment to earnings for deferred revenue not being reflected in revenue, as we had assumed in our guidance. However, since we decided not to report a non-GAAP revenue metric, the top line guidance was off by that amount. It's difference in Health Services will continue and is factored into our new full year revenue guidance, along with a slightly lower run rate in the total revenue that reflects the Q1 shortfall. It is important to note that our Q1 adjusted earnings results were not impacted by the lower revenue, and our annual guidance for adjusted earnings remains the same.
The revenue composition for Q1 was $259 million in system sales, $229 million in support and maintenance, $490 million in services and $18 million in reimbursed travel.
System sales revenues reflected 26% increase over Q1 of '14, with the growth mainly driven by an increase in subscriptions, which is where the addition of Health Services had the biggest impact. Q1 system sales margin dollars grew 19% over the year-ago period. System sales margin percent of 64.7% is down from 68.5% in Q1 of '14 and up from 63.6% in Q4 of '14. The decline in year-over-year reflects lower tech resale margins.
Moving to services. Total services revenue, including professional and managed services, was up 28% compared to Q1 of '14, saw the growth in Cerner services augmented by the addition of Health Services.
Deferred maintenance revenue increased 31% over Q1 of '14, reflecting solid growth in core support and maintenance and the addition of Health Services. 
Looking at revenue by geographic segment. Domestic revenue increased 25% over the year-ago quarter to $871 million and Global revenue grew 44% to $126 million, with both of the growth rates augmented by the addition of Health Services. 
Health Services had a slightly higher mix of Global revenue than Cerner's historical levels. The addition of Health Services had a bigger impact on Global revenue. Our existing Global business has also had a strong performance.
Moving to gross margin. Our gross margin for Q1 was 83.1%, which is down slightly compared to 83.5% in Q1 of '14, reflecting the lower technology resale margins, with slightly lower gross margin from Health Services.
Looking at operating spending. Our first quarter operating expenses before share-based compensation expense and acquisition-related adjustments were $591 million, which is up 28% compared to adjusted Q1 '14 operating expenses. Since we have already integrated many components of Health Services, we don't have an exact breakout of operating expense between Cerner and Health Services. We estimate that Cerner operating expenses grew in the mid-single-digit range and the rest of the growth is the addition of Health Services.
Total year-over-year growth for each expense category was 23% for sales and client service, 41% for software development and 33% for G&A.
Moving to operating margins. Our operating margin before share-based compensation expense and acquisition-related adjustments was 23.7% in Q1. This is down 90 basis points compared to Q1 of '14, reflecting the incorporation of Health Services.
Given we achieved our earnings on lower revenue this quarter, the operating margin percent with Health Services incorporated into our results is higher than we originally projected. This is largely due to lower core Cerner expense growth, offsetting the lower core revenue growth. We expect higher core Cerner revenue growth for the rest of the year but still expect the full year to be below original projections. This is expected to continue being offset by lower expense growth, so we will expect to drive the same level of earnings through a combination of lower revenue and unchanged earnings, leading to a higher core operating margin percent. In total, this means we expect our combined operating margin to only go down approximately 100 to 150 basis points for the year versus an original expectation that it would go down over 200 basis points for the addition of Health Services.
Moving to net earnings and EPS. Our GAAP net earnings in Q1 were $111 million or $0.32 per diluted share. Adjusted net earnings were $157 million and adjusted EPS was $0.45, which is up 22% compared to Q1 of '14. Adjusted net earnings and diluted earnings per share exclude share-based compensation expense, which reduced first quarter 2015 net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $11 million and $0.03, respectively. Adjusted net earnings and diluted earnings per share also reflect adjustments related to the acquisition of Health Services, including amortization of intangibles, which reduced net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $10 million and $0.03, respectively; deferred revenue adjustment, which reduced net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $8 million and $0.02, respectively; and other acquisition-related adjustments, which reduced net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $17 million and $0.05, respectively.
The Q1 tax rate for adjusted net earnings was 33.6%, which is in line with our expected effective tax rate. For the remainder of 2015, we expect our effective tax rate to be in the 33% to 34% range. 
Now I'd like to preview the nonrecurring expense we expect to incur in Q2. We recently offered a voluntary separation plan, or VSP, to eligible associates. Generally, the VSP was made available to U.S. associates who meet the minimum level of combined age and tenure. The VSP was offered to both Cerner and Health Services associates and the percent accepting has been roughly equal across both groups. For some positions, such as executive officers and certain critical roles were excluded from being eligible for business continuity purposes. Associates who elected to participate in the VSP will receive financial benefits commensurate with their tenure and position, along with vacation payout and medical benefits. The acceptance period for associates electing to participate in the VSP ends later this month. Based on levels of acceptance, we currently estimate a net of tax charge of approximately $35 million in Q2 for the VSP and related costs. This completely voluntary program will have a small impact on our total headcount as the eligible associates that accepted the offer only represent about 2% of total associates. While a portion of these positions will be back filled, we believe we will be able to fill many of the positions with existing associates, which should create efficiencies in the future, also creating career growth opportunities for our associates.
Now move to our balance sheet. We ended Q1 with $889 million of total cash and investments, which is down $763 million from $1.65 billion in Q4, mainly driven by a $1.37 billion purchase of Siemens Health Services, partially offset by $500 million of debt that we issued earlier this year and added to cash and investments. Our total debt, including capital lease obligations, is $626 million, up from $130 million in Q4 due to the new debt.
Total receivables at the end of the quarter was $941 million, which is up $268 million from Q4 driven by strong sales in the quarter. The DSO in Q1 was 79 days, which compares to DSO of 66 days in Q4 and 66 days in the year-ago quarter. The increase was driven by higher accounts receivable, which is largely due to adding Health Services and the lower revenue this quarter. We expect DSO to be closer to historical level in future quarters.
Operating cash flow for the quarter was $214 million. Q1 capital expenditures were $82 million, capitalized software was $63 million. 
Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow less capital expenditures and capitalized software, was $69 million for the quarter.
Moving to capitalized software. The $63 million of capitalized software in Q1 represents 39% of the $161 million of total investment in development activities. Software amortization for the quarter was $29 million, resulting in net capitalization of $34 million or 21% of our total R&D investment. We still expect to continue generating solid free cash flow this year, with operating cash flow growth partially offsetting an expected increase in capital expenditures tied to beginning construction of a new campus and capital expenditures related to our Health Services business. Also, the cash flow impact of the VSP will primarily impact Q2 and reduce overall free cash flow for the year.
Now I'll go to Q2 and full year 2015 guidance. For Q2, we expect revenue between $1.175 billion and $1.225 billion, the midpoint reflecting growth of 41% over Q2 of '14. For the full year, we expect revenue between $4.65 billion and $4.8 billion. This is lower than our prior guidance due to the lower revenue in Q1 and expectation for about $1 billion of Health Services revenue for the year instead of our previous expectation of $1.1 billion, which is largely due to the deferred revenue adjustment not impacting the revenue line. This is still 39% growth at the midpoint and reflecting expectation for higher growth in Q1 from core Cerner for the rest of the year.
The low revenue is not expected to impact our earnings in Q2 or for the year. For Q2, we expect adjusted earnings before share based compensation and acquisition related adjustments of $0.51 to $0.52 per share, with the midpoint reflecting 29% growth over Q2 '14 adjusted EPS. For the full year, we expect adjusted EPS before share-based compensation and acquisition-related adjustment to be $2.07 to $2.15, which is up from our previous range of $2.05 to $2.15, reflects 28% growth at the midpoint. Our estimate for the impact of share-based compensation expense is approximately $0.03 to $0.04 in Q2 and $0.14 to $0.15 for the full year.
Moving to bookings guidance. We expect bookings revenue in Q2 of $1.2 billion to $1.3 billion, the midpoint reflecting 16% growth over Q2 of '14. We expect our strong Q1 bookings and Q2 outlook to contribute to better core top line growth as we move through the year. Keep in mind, Q4 has a tough comparable due to the extra week in Q4 '14.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Zane.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. I'll start with our results.Bookings revenue in Q1 of $1.2 billion reflects very strong growth, up 32% over Q1 2014. Bookings this q
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. I'll start with our results.
Bookings revenue in Q1 of $1.2 billion reflects very strong growth, up 32% over Q1 2014. Bookings this quarter included a high level of large contracts, with 24 contracts over $5 million, including 19 over $10 million. We also had a strong contribution from long-term bookings, with an ITWorks contract and an expansion of existing RevWorks relationship. This led to long-term bookings making up 37% of the total, which is approximately 5% higher than normal. Even adjusting out the higher-term long-term bookings contribution, our bookings were very strong and bookings would still be at the high end of our guidance.
As Marc discussed, our strong bookings didn't convert to high revenue this quarter, but it does position us for higher future growth. A highlight of the quarter was strong competitiveness, which resulted in 34% of our bookings coming from outside our core Millennium installed base. As I discussed during our investment community meeting at HIMSS, our pipeline is very strong and we are well positioned for new business this year and beyond.
I believe we still have a multiyear period ahead of us, where there will be opportunities to win new footprints as organizations look to replace legacy systems and align with a strategic supplier. There's also a meaningful opportunity to expand our footprints within our client base as many of our large clients still have several non-Cerner facilities and are looking to consolidate on a single system. The ongoing acquisition activity in the marketplace plays to our advantage as well because it is being led by our clients. We are already off to a good start with migrating Health Services clients to Millennium, and this activity is bringing along sales with other solutions, such as Population Health and Ambulatory. My view of our opportunities was reinforced at HIMSS where we interacted more than $5 billion of pipeline, including many new EMR replacement opportunities.
In addition to strong new business activity, the dominant themes at HIMSS align very well with Cerner's strengths. Our complete vision and strong capabilities in Population Health, coupled with our commitment to interoperability and an open EMR were clearly on display and well received.
Regarding interoperability, we were pleased with the level of progress that was on display during the conference, most notably CommonWell member expansion to over 70% of the acute EMR market being represented.
Now I'll briefly discuss a few key areas of our business, starting with Population Health. Our Population Health organization had a strong start to the year. We continue to have success with selling Population Health solutions to clients ranging from small hospitals to IDNs, counties and states. Population Health solutions are now part of most new EMR contracts, and as I mentioned, have been added to migration contracts for Health Services clients converting to Millennium. Overall, I believe our differentiation in Population Health is becoming clear. We are quickly separating ourselves from other offerings with our ability to aggregate and normalize clinical, financial and claims data across multiple systems and bring near real-time information into the workflow.
Another key differentiator is results. Our early adopter clients, such as Advocate Health Care, are getting value out of the system and are vocal about the fact that they view Healthe Intent as a platform that improves their ability to operate in an environment in which they are taking on more risk.
Moving to our Revenue Cycle business. We had a good first quarter and have a strong outlook for the year. Revenue Cycle continues to be an important component of EMR replacement opportunities, and the strength of our integrated Revenue Cycle offering is contributing to our success at gaining new footprints. We're also continuing to increase penetration of our Revenue Cycle solutions in our client base in both acute and ambulatory venues as clients look to move to a single platform. We are still early in this opportunity, and I expect many more of our large clients to move to our Revenue Cycle solutions now that we have more proof points among our large clients.
On the RevWorks services side of our business, we expanded our relationship with an existing RevWorks client based on success we've had so far. I am pleased with how we have executed on our initial RevWorks relationships and we are achieving results that I believe will be compelling to other prospects. For example, Adventist Health Northern California region has achieved a $27 million increase in revenue, a 21% decrease in AR days and all of their sites are over 100% of the cash targets. These types of results reflect the strength of both our Revenue Cycle solutions and our RevWorks services offerings and create compelling reasons for new prospects to consider our Revenue Cycle solutions and services.
Moving to the Ambulatory market, where we had a strong Q1. Noteworthy activity in Q1 included continued displacements of key competitors, including the displacement of ambulatory solutions of our primary competitor at 29 ambulatory facilities; a strong start at selling ambulatory solutions into the Health Services base, including stand-alone sales and being included as part of acute-care migrations to Millennium; and continued strength in our ambulatory business office services.
Regarding business office services, I'd like to highlight that business because I think success there is not widely known. We currently have ambulatory business office services clients across 45 specialties in 39 states. Our clients range from single physician practices, up to the large IDNs where we have RevWorks relationships that include ambulatory business office services. As we have gained traction in this space, we are identifying more opportunities to displace a cloud competitor's business office services by proving our offering is more effective. For example, we are able to show, in many cases, our business office services are more than 20% less than our competitor's cloud offering, primarily because they require the client to maintain a staff approximately 3x our offering requires. In addition, many of these larger and more sophisticated clients are facing several challenges with our competitor's solutions, which is having 50% to 60% of the claims requiring manual intervention because they don't fit the cloud configuration. I believe that we will keep doing well in this business office services space as we continue to gain positive proof points with our clients and as awareness broadens about the true cost and challenges associated with our cloud competitor.
Outside the U.S. we had a strong Q1. Total revenue growth was 44%, consisting of strong organic growth and the addition of Health Services. Strong performance in the U.K. was a big driver of our organic growth as we continue to have success gaining new footprints and expanding relationships with clients as they transition out of the national program. One of the reasons we continue to do well in the market is that our clients are getting value out of the solutions. A great example of this was documented when the Health and Social Care Information Center did a benefits deep dive of the Cerner Millennium implementation at Barts Health NHS Trust, which is the largest hospital trust in England. In this review, they concluded Barts as achieving significant clinical and operational benefits in areas where Cerner Millennium isn't sold. This and other proof points as we have in the U.K. market position us very well relative to our less established competitors. Broadly, we remain optimistic about our ability to get good contributions from Global for the rest of the decade, and this opportunity is enhanced by the complementary global business at Health Services.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks and provide some comments on our initial go-lives with Intermountain Healthcare.I'll start with ITWorks. In the first quarter, we established a new ITWorks relationship and also
componenttext:
Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks and provide some comments on our initial go-lives with Intermountain Healthcare.
I'll start with ITWorks. In the first quarter, we established a new ITWorks relationship and also expanded an existing ITWorks relationship. Our new ITWorks client is a 410-bed community hospital with 29 ambulatory locations. Similar to many of our ITWorks clients, taking over IT operations is only part of the new contract. For example, as Zane discussed, we'll be displacing our primary competitor in the ambulatory facilities. We will also be doing an optimization project for the clients' Millennium system at the hospital and implement a Population Health and Revenue Cycle solutions. A memo to all system employees, a CEO of our client highlighted the strategic nature of the ITWorks engagement by saying, "we believe it's the best approach to ensure we meet our long-term strategic objectives of our organization, while continuing to provide the highest level of care to our patients in an era of incredibly fast-moving changes in healthcare, information technology and increasing regulatory requirements." As indicated on our last call, our ITWorks pipeline is strong, as many provider organizations face pressure to control cost, improve quality and keep up with regulatory requirements. In Q1, our results are a good start and I expect continued success throughout the year.
Now I'd like to make a few comments on our initial go-lives at 2 Intermountain Healthcare hospitals and 24 clinics. The go-lives occurred just 15 months after we signed the contract, which is extremely fast when you consider the majority of projects of similar scope take more than 2x as long. When fully deployed, project iCentra will be at 22 hospitals and more than 180 clinics. It will include nearly 80 solutions across EHR, practice management and Revenue Cycle and the system will have over 320 role profiles, 354 clinical workflow models and 372 financial workflow models. This is the first Cerner project to make use of our new agile development methodology, a model that represents the departure from the industry-standard waterfall implementation approach. In the agile model, physicians and other end users participate in the system build and design, never go more than 6 weeks within an opportunity to see, use and give feedback on the system prior to go-live. This approach has been a big success, and we believe there are benefits that will extend beyond the go-live. It has the potential to support elements of a learning health system, something that has been elusive in healthcare.
Another key element of this project is the incorporation of Intermountain's Care Process Models and clinical process guidelines, which have helped these clinicians to achieve high-quality care and lower overall cost for many years. Before iCentra, these were mostly paper documents. Now they are all part of the digital workflows that are used every day.
In summary, we believe our work with Intermountain, combined with the work we are doing with other strategic client partners, is resulting in a new generation of systems. We are leading the transition in the industry away from systems that are simply transactional or used for the purposes of meeting regulatory requirements. We're creating intelligent systems design to meet the complex needs of providers across the spectrum of healthcare, coordinating care at any time, any place, with intelligence to inform decisions at the high standards and connecting all of the individuals they serve seamlessly into that process.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to questions.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Marc, I just wanted to dive in a little bit on the Cerner core a bit. You talked about the fact that you had a $50 million shortfall versus your guidance, about 50-50 split between the core and the Cerner Health Services business. If I think about the
componenttext: So Marc, I just wanted to dive in a little bit on the Cerner core a bit. You talked about the fact that you had a $50 million shortfall versus your guidance, about 50-50 split between the core and the Cerner Health Services business. If I think about the core, how much -- how many of the -- how much of the shortfall was items that you've had historically like the -- some of the third-party tech resale versus, I know you had a really strong booking -- long-term bookings number. Was there anything else that surprised you in terms of why that number missed that you haven't seen in the past, I guess?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the onetime revenue was slightly lower than we expected. Much of that was from tech resale, which obviously is -- means you don't get [indiscernible] of revenue, but it doesn't really impact earnings very much. The other piece was services and tra
componenttext: I think the onetime revenue was slightly lower than we expected. Much of that was from tech resale, which obviously is -- means you don't get [indiscernible] of revenue, but it doesn't really impact earnings very much. The other piece was services and travel was lower. Some of the services related to just contract signing timeframes and project start dates were a little bit later than we expected, so we didn't start turning that revenue spigot on as early in the quarter as we felt we would, and that also impact the reimbursed travel. Usually, reimbursed travel is the number that I pay very little attention to other than managing it from an expense standpoint because it's 0 revenue or 0 margin. But that one was actually significantly lower than we would have projected as we came into the quarter. So I don't know, there was no real surprises. And as we look out for the rest of the year, Q2 through Q4, we get back on track for the most part, then, I think delivering more according to what we're planning and forecasting.

Some of those can fall a little bit later than we would've projected. The mix -- there was nothing major in the mix, still strong software, just little probably weaker tech resale and lower margin on the tech resale we did get.

So when you think about those other health system that are similar in size, can you just kind of like share with us how with that pipeline is looking? And do you need to kind of like first implement all the 22 hospitals of Intermountain, or should we expect to see a deal kind of like it looks at that type of intelligent systems before that?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Marc. Relative to Intermountain, we will first go-live. I think that once we get the second set turned on, I think we'll have proof points for people that are interested in going and seeing what that model system, if you will, looks like. But I do
componenttext: This is Marc. Relative to Intermountain, we will first go-live. I think that once we get the second set turned on, I think we'll have proof points for people that are interested in going and seeing what that model system, if you will, looks like. But I don't know that it's going to significantly impact the timing of opportunities that are at their size. Interesting enough, it directly impacts one of the bigger opportunities, which is DOD, that's out there and they were working with Intermountain on relative to the model systems that we're going to implement there. But the timing of those projects and the turn on dates really are separate concept. A lot of Intermountain helps us with when we talk is their concept and their approach and embedding the content to make the healthcare more effective and to actually help manage the health of the population. So a lot of what they're doing is from kind of a sales perspective is just sharing that message. And then as we do go-lives, we'll be able to show it out live and up and running. But given the first one is going live, given next set coming, but given the projects staying in good shape, timing of any of those doesn't preclude us from pursuing those opportunities.

They've held pretty true to their timelines for the most part and it's been a pretty effective procurement process. So we'd anticipate that they will continue along that path of hitting their timeline and make the, probably, the end of the second quarter, but it could go into the early third quarter.

componenttextpreview: This is Zane, I'll start and then, I'll let Marc finish as it relates to the composition. Most all of our new EMR business has some Population Health as part of that. And we would include things like registries as part of a core solution set and that's pa
componenttext: This is Zane, I'll start and then, I'll let Marc finish as it relates to the composition. Most all of our new EMR business has some Population Health as part of that. And we would include things like registries as part of a core solution set and that's part of a key differentiators as we move forward, because our ability to get the data back into clinicians' workflow at the Point of Care and near real-time is the key differentiator between us and all other competitors. And so you see that as one of the core elements as what we do. So nearly all of the new business has that related to that. It's -- I'll set Marc up for the second piece of that. It tends to be a smaller portion upfront, so it's not a significant portion of that contract bookings in that it typically is that kind of what I'll call it starter set for Population Health around registries and really sets up the footprint for Pop Health and the opportunity to go back and sell back into the base over time.

componenttext: Yes, and that's exactly right, Zane. Most of the economics that we expect on a per member per month basis are in the future for some of those we put in the platform or some revenue related to that initial work. But for the most part -- and a lot of their initial projects are pilot in nature, so even when it goes live and goes on a PMPM basis, we don't have quite so many of them.

componenttextpreview: The patient registry is really that -- provides the ability for the clinician to understand what the disease state is of that person and run the protocols for that particular scenario, and that's a very normal part of a particularly ambulatory process. Th
componenttext: The patient registry is really that -- provides the ability for the clinician to understand what the disease state is of that person and run the protocols for that particular scenario, and that's a very normal part of a particularly ambulatory process. The PMPM portions will come up in the future. Kind of the next piece is you'll see us around is in the Enterprise Data Warehouse elements, and we're seeing client uptake on that side that has -- that does have some PMPM elements to it. We have a number of offerings that will come out throughout the year as we move to programs and to some other areas, and those are all PMPM basis.

componenttext: Probably the next big one coming out is healthcare management, that's a key element. So once you identify through your registries, the people that are high risk, then how do you go manage their care in an effective manner. So those are the 2 -- keep in mind, while each of the solutions that we put on this platform, which we expect to be certainly in the double-digit range, all have the PMPM factors that PMPM price may vary based on the influence of those solutions and certainly, doing the registries and the Care Management are 2 of the key components to that architecture.

componenttextpreview: Marc, can you talk a little bit about looking at the backlog? What are the dynamics of your backlog conversion capabilities? Specifically, what kind of levers do you guys have available to either throttle up or throttle down conversion of backlog into rev
componenttext: Marc, can you talk a little bit about looking at the backlog? What are the dynamics of your backlog conversion capabilities? Specifically, what kind of levers do you guys have available to either throttle up or throttle down conversion of backlog into revenue?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, for the most part, having a big backlog gives you good visibility. While a lot of the visibility we have in our backlog doesn't -- isn't one that you're going to throttle up or down a whole lot, a lot of it is hours worked based on the project activ
componenttext: Well, for the most part, having a big backlog gives you good visibility. While a lot of the visibility we have in our backlog doesn't -- isn't one that you're going to throttle up or down a whole lot, a lot of it is hours worked based on the project activity that's going on, so a lot of services, a lot of the backlog is a, you're going to pay me x amount a month for a 10-year period. So a lot of it is less subject to growing and changing relative to our revenue outlook. So when we go into a quarter and start looking at revenue in a quarter like this, you're really looking primarily at things that are more near-term revenue that can impact your level of revenue for that quarter. But you've got other -- everything else is basically subscription, support, all those elements are coming out of backlog, but there are not a lot of -- there's not a lot of levers that we can go. I can't take a 6 month services project and take 6x the number of people and go work for one month really fast to drive that revenue out.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. That makes sense. Let me ask it a different way. How much of the backlog would you say is related to projects or contracts that are currently in process versus those that are for future periods, then? Or is that just not that right way to look at i
componenttext: Right. That makes sense. Let me ask it a different way. How much of the backlog would you say is related to projects or contracts that are currently in process versus those that are for future periods, then? Or is that just not that right way to look at it?

componenttext: Right. You're kind of asking what is backlog going to contribute to the next period.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

componenttext: Well just trying to see how much visibility one has, near term versus long term relative to the 10 quarters-or-so of revenue that are represented at backlog today.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think if you wait for the backlog, certainly it waits toward current. I mean, you need to look at average life, it might be 3.5 years, but there's a higher percentage of that, that occurs in the first 12 months relative to the overall 10 years-
componenttext: Yes, and I think if you wait for the backlog, certainly it waits toward current. I mean, you need to look at average life, it might be 3.5 years, but there's a higher percentage of that, that occurs in the first 12 months relative to the overall 10 years-plus potential of the backlog. So I think we've got -- when we go into a quarter, there's probably 85% to 90% of the revenue is visible coming out of that backlog. So maybe that's a good answer to you. If I look at the full year from today, kind about 12 months, I'm about probably 75% because there'll be things that get in the backlog, that would help me feed those out-quarter P&Ls. But when I go into this next quarter, I'm about 85% to 90%, so pretty high correlation, so that's why a little bit -- we don't normally have a lower-revenue quarter.

Is that the right way to look at it?

componenttext: I think when you talk about the -- from our perspective, we would always indicate that we'd expect to grow Cerner revenue at kind of basically low double-digit rate. So, say, 10%. So based on our number, that's kind of what we would have expected. We were below that in Q1, but we expect to get closer to that as we go through Q2 through the end of the quarter, probably high single digit to ending the year in total. So if you're looking at that for Cerner, then kind of you do the math and just subtracting, come up with what the HS is. We look at HS delivered for this year, right about $1 billion of revenue. And so that was the number that Dave was asking about relative to -- originally we were at looking about $1.1 billion, so there's $100 million just on the HS side for the full year. Half of that is deferred revenue being -- not being in the revenue line and half of it is just tweaking the revenue projections for the rest of the year for them.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

componenttext: Okay. That's useful. And then, moving to the international side. You mentioned top line growth, 44%, all in. Could you break that out as to what portion was legacy Cerner? And specifically, on U.K., I think you mentioned momentum as clients move from government systems. So just trying to get a better idea of how to think about it. Where do you think you are in terms of building momentum in that area? And how long will this outsized opportunity last, do you think? Just to help us out.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think from a bookings perspective, certainly, U.K., as trusts are transitioning now to government program, we had a very strong performance. Part of the reason we had good performance in the larger contracts is we had 3 U.K. contracts that qualified as
componenttext: I think from a bookings perspective, certainly, U.K., as trusts are transitioning now to government program, we had a very strong performance. Part of the reason we had good performance in the larger contracts is we had 3 U.K. contracts that qualified as over $10 million. So those trusts coming out and purchasing -- globally, there is a focus on healthcare and on technology, and it's really trying to match up the available resources and spending in each country, relative to being able to procure it since '08, '09, that's been fairly light, starting to see that rebound, starting to see more interest within Continental Europe. I think certainly, bringing Siemens in the fold has solidified us as a very credible and key choice in the European markets. And there are still countrywide procurements that are ongoing as we speak that we have a much better positioning for because of that acquisition. But I think we still see a lot of opportunity, globally. I think even if you go outside Europe and start looking at North America, I think Canada is probably as good an opportunity in the next 12 months as we've seen for quite some, time. So it kind of -- starting to see a little bit of a mirror in our overall pipeline, which is the strongest we've ever seen as we go into '15 that we're starting to see some good strength in targeted areas, globally.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. In fact, every piece of our pipeline picked up in terms of -- across our business, our install business, our core client development U.S. business and our Global marketplace. And as Marc described, we have a number of opportunities across el
componenttext: This is Zane. In fact, every piece of our pipeline picked up in terms of -- across our business, our install business, our core client development U.S. business and our Global marketplace. And as Marc described, we have a number of opportunities across elements of -- outside the U.S. as well as back to unprecedented activity that we've seen in the U.S. in terms of number of decisions. We see approximately 50% more decisions in the U.S. and we've seen --  than we saw last year in 2014. The level of activity is presentations and demos are all-time highs and well over 50% increase year-over-year. So the activity levels across the business have picked up quite a bit. So from a bookings perspective and looking forward, we are as optimistic as we've ever been about the growth of the business and the health of that.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And to give you a sense on Global, just our bookings growth was double-digit year-over-year in those, in our Global markets, which is very good strength and consistent with our strong growth in the U.S.
componenttext: And to give you a sense on Global, just our bookings growth was double-digit year-over-year in those, in our Global markets, which is very good strength and consistent with our strong growth in the U.S.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Steve Halper from FBR.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Steve Halper from FBR.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just a couple of questions. First, you mentioned some project time frames slipping, which led to lower service revenues. Have those picked up yet in line with your expectation?
componenttext: So just a couple of questions. First, you mentioned some project time frames slipping, which led to lower service revenues. Have those picked up yet in line with your expectation?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: It wasn't really slipping as much as just the start of those projects, Steve, especially with a lot of new contracts getting signed. Depending on the projects, we can start some of those projects, the landing projects, we'll start some of them even early
componenttext: It wasn't really slipping as much as just the start of those projects, Steve, especially with a lot of new contracts getting signed. Depending on the projects, we can start some of those projects, the landing projects, we'll start some of them even early in the process just to start the revenue stream going. And for this period, we didn't really have as much of that as we often do, relative to getting revenue streams started in the quarter. Once it gets started, which those are starting as we speak, then, the revenue stream continues and delivers the starts delivering a very predictable stream out of the backlog. But in the quarter sign, there is an element, especially when you have the level of bookings that we had and the level of new clients that we had, the projects starts did not align exactly with some of our modeling, which is somewhat of an art as opposed to a science. But that's primarily what we saw in Q1 and that's why we really don't see it in Q2 because now they're in the backlog and we're covered for that.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And then relative to the deferred revenue from Health Services, shouldn't have that been reflected in the original guidance?
componenttext: Right. And then relative to the deferred revenue from Health Services, shouldn't have that been reflected in the original guidance?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we -- that deferred revenue was a number that we included in our revenue guidance as we, at that point, thought that we would be reflecting it as revenue in the income, in the adjusted income statement. We decided it would be clearer to just have ad
componenttext: Well, we -- that deferred revenue was a number that we included in our revenue guidance as we, at that point, thought that we would be reflecting it as revenue in the income, in the adjusted income statement. We decided it would be clearer to just have adjustments to a net earnings line, which means that we didn't have an adjusted earning or a non-GAAP revenue number, or we do have a non-GAAP earnings number. Since it didn't go in that number, it's not reported as revenue and it's not -- it's a difference between what we would have had in our heads when we've provided guidance and the number that got delivered.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. So it's a little apples-to-oranges; comparison.
componenttext: Right. So it's a little apples-to-oranges; comparison.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, right, it's a number that we felt would be in them and isn't, but it doesn't really impact the results.
componenttext: Yes, right, it's a number that we felt would be in them and isn't, but it doesn't really impact the results.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And lastly, just as a follow-up on Health Services. You're past the HIMSS conference, we're a couple of months in. Can you characterize any conversations that you've had with the Health Service clients about your conversion to Millennium, new sales
componenttext: Right. And lastly, just as a follow-up on Health Services. You're past the HIMSS conference, we're a couple of months in. Can you characterize any conversations that you've had with the Health Service clients about your conversion to Millennium, new sales into that base? Any sort of color you can give us around the progression there.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. This is Zane. We had 3 clients that actually made decisions in the first quarter to go from a Siemens legacy -- Health Services legacy solution to a Cerner Millennium full EHR decision, which was very, very good uptick. We had a number of Hea
componenttext: Sure, Steve. This is Zane. We had 3 clients that actually made decisions in the first quarter to go from a Siemens legacy -- Health Services legacy solution to a Cerner Millennium full EHR decision, which was very, very good uptick. We had a number of Health Services clients that added Cerner Solutions to the mix. So ambulatory, population health, surgery, we saw a number of elements where those Health Services clients picked up and made some decisions to complete the portfolio. So I was very pleased with the performance in the first quarter and the start that we had in that space. We are also working with those same clients. There are many of them that want to continue on the journey of the Soarian solutions or on a combined strategy of Cerner on the clinicals and Soarian or other legacy solutions on the financial side. And we're supportive of those and the reception has been very good. We hosted a breakfast at HIMSS for a number of those clients and it was very well received and well attended. And so I'm very pleased with the clients' perspective of how we are performing and the receptivity to Cerner as the custodian of the legacy solutions, as well as those that are moving forward with the Cerner Millennium and other solution set. So that's been very, very positive.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one follow-up. So obviously, those discussions with those 3 clients were already underway. But since the acquisition was announced or closed, did that process speed up because of the acquisition?
componenttext: And just one follow-up. So obviously, those discussions with those 3 clients were already underway. But since the acquisition was announced or closed, did that process speed up because of the acquisition?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: It did. They moved very quickly. So a couple of those actually moved very quickly to make a decision to move forward with us. And I think some of the -- we did not have a lot of bookings contribution from the Health Services business itself, which I think
componenttext: It did. They moved very quickly. So a couple of those actually moved very quickly to make a decision to move forward with us. And I think some of the -- we did not have a lot of bookings contribution from the Health Services business itself, which I think makes sense as you had some of that client base waiting to see how the transition would occur and what, in fact, happened. So I would anticipate a better contribution from the pure Health Services clients themselves on the more legacy solutions as we move forward. But the contribution was very minimal in the first quarter.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Marc. Just a couple of data. I think, actually, when we look at booking, going forward, and the guidance that we gave, we're assuming pretty minimal contribution from HS bookings just because we think, a lot of -- we just don't think that t
componenttext: Steve, this is Marc. Just a couple of data. I think, actually, when we look at booking, going forward, and the guidance that we gave, we're assuming pretty minimal contribution from HS bookings just because we think, a lot of -- we just don't think that they're -- as they're still ramping up and they're still working through the clients, a lot of the clients are going to make decisions. Those are going to be buying Millennium solutions for some form or fashion, as Zane talked about, I think that we don't really -- are not looking for a great -- much of an impact at all from HS bookings for this, actually, full year. But the one thing that strikes me on HS is that we kind of have a strategy of running those 2 companies kind of parallel. We didn't want to distract those organizations, your organization. We're coming together a lot faster than I would've expected, and smooth transition. The client-side is almost we just have our Q2 forecast meeting a week ago and it's pretty amazing how seamless it feels that we're talking as one company, looking at all of the opportunities across both sides. I think that's one of the reasons that as we look out and try to track the numbers, we're really focusing on kind of the one big number we've been trying to come up with our official breakdowns between HS and Cerner, because we are getting together more quickly than I would have expected, which is actually great, given that it's being done pretty seamlessly. So I'd just thought I'd throw that in for color.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question come from the line of Dave Windley from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question come from the line of Dave Windley from Jefferies.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Marc, I thought I understood this, but now I'm confused. On the deferred revenue, your answer to Steve, they're talking about it not being in the revenue because you're -- it sounds like you're basically saying you're presenting it differently than you or
componenttext: Marc, I thought I understood this, but now I'm confused. On the deferred revenue, your answer to Steve, they're talking about it not being in the revenue because you're -- it sounds like you're basically saying you're presenting it differently than you originally anticipated doing. But do I understand correctly that the absence of that revenue, so trading it as deferred instead of running through the revenue line, does have a bottom line impact, does it not?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it doesn't. The difference was that I knew that there was a number for deferred revenue that under GAAP, you wouldn't recognize but as an adjusted item and given that it was in the run rate, our expectation was we would recognize it. The difference is
componenttext: No, it doesn't. The difference was that I knew that there was a number for deferred revenue that under GAAP, you wouldn't recognize but as an adjusted item and given that it was in the run rate, our expectation was we would recognize it. The difference is -- so the number was always going to be in the earnings line. The difference really is presentation. When we've guided revenue prior to the quarter, I would have put that $12.5 million in my revenue number that I guided to results that we presented. We don't have it in the revenue number. They have it as a separate line, adjusting net earnings. So it still has the same impact on earnings. There's no change. But from a presentation standpoint, revenue that we talked about today is $12.5 million less than what I thought it would have been when we did our guidance. So that's...

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the paragraph on the front of the press release where it does say the deferred revenue, which reduced net earnings and diluted earnings per share, is that something different?
componenttext: In the paragraph on the front of the press release where it does say the deferred revenue, which reduced net earnings and diluted earnings per share, is that something different?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is relative to GAAP net earnings, not including that deferred revenue, resulted in a lower GAAP number. So our adjusted earnings, basically, takes the GAAP number as a starting point and that was reduced by the deferred revenue and then add that defe
componenttext: That is relative to GAAP net earnings, not including that deferred revenue, resulted in a lower GAAP number. So our adjusted earnings, basically, takes the GAAP number as a starting point and that was reduced by the deferred revenue and then add that deferred revenue item back to get to the adjusted earnings, which we think is a more -- a better indicator to investors of the performance of the company.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fine. Sorry for that. So moving on to a more important question. The expansions of -- I guess the longer-term contracts, which is a good number in the quarter, and the expansions of longer-term contracts, I'm curious, on those works situations where
componenttext: Okay. Fine. Sorry for that. So moving on to a more important question. The expansions of -- I guess the longer-term contracts, which is a good number in the quarter, and the expansions of longer-term contracts, I'm curious, on those works situations where you get those expansions, what are the triggers for those? Are those situations where the client was piloting and part of their enterprise? Or where they've acquired something and the acquired facility needs that expansion? What drives an existing client to expand, rather than taking an enterprise-wide, to begin with?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. It's a number of considerations. Often time, it's acquisition activity. So they've made an acquisition who had a competitor's EMR and they've not yet gotten to that rollout. In some cases, there were decisions to pilot those decision -- thos
componenttext: This is Zane. It's a number of considerations. Often time, it's acquisition activity. So they've made an acquisition who had a competitor's EMR and they've not yet gotten to that rollout. In some cases, there were decisions to pilot those decision -- those -- that EMR and get a certain set up and running. And you often see that in the investor-owned segment where they start with a subset of their hospitals and will decide, based on success, to continue to roll out. And we see that happening at a number of our investor own clients.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think relative to some of the expansions on the works deal, those -- some of those will be based on -- some clients do have a smaller starting point. Some clients start with a certain term and say we like this, we like how this is going, so we're going
componenttext: I think relative to some of the expansions on the works deal, those -- some of those will be based on -- some clients do have a smaller starting point. Some clients start with a certain term and say we like this, we like how this is going, so we're going to expand the term of our license. So it's adding years. And keep in mind, each of these works businesses can have different flavors. So we can go anywhere from a full works business to maybe, they only had AMS and some other support services that they've signed up for and then they signed up the works. So expansion usually can either mean they've acquired more facilities and those are going to fall in under the original contract to support. It could be the length of the term or could be an expansion of the actual services that they want us to have. Keep in mind, we've talk about that this year, we think -- we're seeing a lot of ITWorks opportunities as you kind of think on a revenue growth perspective, those add $7 million to $10 million on an annual basis. And if we can get to the point where we're signing 4 or 5 of those in a year or more, and that's a good opportunity to expand the top line as well.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And my last question, I think, a quick one. But at the HIMSS Analyst Day, you talked about 5 Soarian clients making the decision to shift over to Millennium. And Zane, I think you just said 3 during the first quarter. And so I just wanted to make sure I was understanding the 2 numbers correctly and perhaps, you could update, has there been any subsequent decision to what we heard at the Analyst Day?

componenttext: Sorry about that. So there were -- one of those had 3 hospitals that were kind of 3 individual, buying decisions that I have, in my head, have rolled that into 1. The 5 is accurate element of that, but principally driven by 1. So those -- 'that's still the same as you think about where we were from HIMSS previously.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And for the most part, we expect there to be migrations as we go. It's not a metric that we're going to kind of track every quarter, but I think it was from Dick's comments at HIMSS and our comments today, it's noteworthy that within 60 days of closing, w
componenttext: And for the most part, we expect there to be migrations as we go. It's not a metric that we're going to kind of track every quarter, but I think it was from Dick's comments at HIMSS and our comments today, it's noteworthy that within 60 days of closing, we still had 5, basically, transactions with 3 basic clients that made the decision to go with Cerner and do the migration very quickly. So that was more of the data point that we expect. Once again, that will be, over time, a very good chunk of their base will migrate to Cerner Solutions in some form or another.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're still seeing very good activity in the transition space.
componenttext: We're still seeing very good activity in the transition space.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question from the line of Sean Wieland from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And your next question from the line of Sean Wieland from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this quarter and last quarter, you've talked about the expanded pipeline in the hospital market. Can you just talk a little bit about the close rate that you're seeing in that pipeline and what, if any, is the sense of urgency that these customers have
componenttext: So this quarter and last quarter, you've talked about the expanded pipeline in the hospital market. Can you just talk a little bit about the close rate that you're seeing in that pipeline and what, if any, is the sense of urgency that these customers have in making a decision?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great question. Sean, it is different than it was in a Meaningful Use era where the timelines were really forced by the [indiscernible] related to that Meaningful Use thesis. So we are seeing some variability in the close rates of those decisions and the
componenttext: Great question. Sean, it is different than it was in a Meaningful Use era where the timelines were really forced by the [indiscernible] related to that Meaningful Use thesis. So we are seeing some variability in the close rates of those decisions and the ability to accurately forecast some of the timing of that. The level of activity is unprecedented, but the close rate does have some variability as we move forward. There are compelling elements as people look to the future. They know that they have to have a contemporary solution set. And so the more at-risk dollars that they have around readmissions and so the more that their revenue is at risk, so as they look forward, they have a number of mandates from the government and from the payer side around their risk elements. And so they need to go move forward. It's a matter of how much pain can the -- will they allow themselves to be inflicted upon before they move to a more contemporary system. So that really is the key driver of the close rate of that. But we've had a very extensive forecast methodology that we continue to utilize and has really helped us take the variability out of the business, and that discipline is what we utilize to run and re-forecast our business every quarter for the following 4 quarters

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Marc. The next part is having a big pipeline and lots of activity means we can apply risk to closure. And so if something moves out, there's usually something else is taking its place. So pipeline makes -- increases your forecast ability even
componenttext: Yes, this is Marc. The next part is having a big pipeline and lots of activity means we can apply risk to closure. And so if something moves out, there's usually something else is taking its place. So pipeline makes -- increases your forecast ability even in an environment where there isn't a special particular date that is driving closure to contract.

componenttext: I have to go do the research to figure that out. Obviously, if their power works fine, very likely, they are up and running. But I think for the most part, those displacements are likely going to be other solutions that will have a normal project standpoint.

componenttext: It's actually Stephan calling in for Bob. Just wanted to follow-up on the comments around the strong pipeline. More broadly, I was hoping you can share your thoughts around what you've seen with regards to overall client CapEx budget, so improving utilization. Is there an improvement in backdrop of or ACO volume driven improvement that's driving increased activity?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. Obviously, our business is impacted by the health of our clients. And many of our clients have seen a large amount of volume increase, and so that, obviously, is a positive element on that. And then those clients that have better reimburseme
componenttext: This is Zane. Obviously, our business is impacted by the health of our clients. And many of our clients have seen a large amount of volume increase, and so that, obviously, is a positive element on that. And then those clients that have better reimbursement scenarios in certain states that have received some of the Medicaid additional dollars, their bottom lines have been positively impacted. I won't say that, that's driving additional spending behavior because fundamentally, what our clients are looking at is the future to both survive and then thrive. And so these are core decisions that the clients need to make. And so while their financial health will have impact on our business, overall, making the investments in these types of systems is actually crucial for their survival long term and ability to thrive. So I don't think that it's going to have an immediate near-term impact so much as it has -- it's good when our clients are doing well.
