headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Cerner Corporation second quarter 2015 conference call. Today's date is August 4, 2015, and this call is being recorded.The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, inc
componenttext:
Welcome to the Cerner Corporation second quarter 2015 conference call. Today's date is August 4, 2015, and this call is being recorded.
The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, including without limitation those regarding projections of future revenues or earnings, operating margins, operating expenses, product development, new markets or prospects for the company solutions and plans and expectations related to the Health Services business and other client achievements. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by the forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements may be found under Item 1A in Cerner's Form 10-K together with the company's other filings.
A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed in this earnings call can be found in the company's earnings release, which was furnished to the SEC today and posted on the Investors section of www.cerner.com.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call to Marc Naughton, Chief Financial Officer of Cerner Corporation.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call. I'll lead off today with a review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will me follow me with the results highlights and marketplace observations. Mike Neal, Executive Vice President and
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call. I'll lead off today with a review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will me follow me with the results highlights and marketplace observations. Mike Neal, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, will discuss operations. Neal Patterson, our Chairman and CEO, will join us for Q&A.
Now I'll turn to our results. Similar to last quarter, we delivered results that were mostly in line with our expectations with the exception of revenue. While we are disappointed that we are below our guided levels of revenue, the continued level of strong bookings and positive outlook [indiscernible] a good second half of the year.
Our bookings revenue in Q2 was $1.29 billion, which is an all-time high and reflects 20% over Q2 of '14, including record amounts of new business activity. Our revenue backlog at the end of the quarter was $13.3 billion and is up $9.7 billion a year ago and reflects the strong bookings in Q2 as well as the inclusion of backlog from Health Services.
Revenue in the quarter was $1.13 billion, which is up 32% over Q2 of '14 and includes approximately $260 million of Health Services. The total is approximately $50 million below our guidance range with approximately $40 million of shortfall related to core Cerner and $10 million attributable to Health Services.
On the Cerner side, the low revenue results in low single-digit growth related to several factors. Some are in quarter dynamics, some are unique items in the prior-year period that drove 20% growth and created a tough comparable and some other items that we didn't accurately forecast.
The first factor is lower growth in services, which is primarily because of a year-over-year decrease in third-party services. Recall that in Q2 of '14, we added revenue [indiscernible] more than $20 million, which is largely related to higher third-party services and reimbursed travel. We are using less third-party services this year, and travel revenue, excluding Health Services, was down approximately 50% year-over-year. Adjusting for these 2 items bring Cerner's core growth from approximately 2% to 5%. As you know, third-party services are lower margins, and the reimbursed travel is 0 margin. So this lower revenue had lower impact on our profitability.
Another factor that has impacted our services revenue is that we limited hiring in the months leading up to and the initial months after the close of our Health Services acquisition.
Our forecasted model did not fully reflect this, we're now ramping up hiring to meet the strong demand reflected in year-to-date bookings and our forecast, which will drive stronger services revenues growth. But the impact of these additional resources as well as the impact of additional opportunities you see for the works businesses will primarily be toward the end of the year and in 2016. 
An additional factor impacting revenues and our bookings this quarter included a higher percentage from long-term contracts resulting in lower percentage of items we generated in core revenue. 
Finally, related to Health Services. The current revenue is tracking as we have forecasted, but nonrecurring revenue came in lower than expected. Although we have ongoing success with converting Health Services clients to Millennium, there's a portion of their base sitting tighter in the transition which is impacted the rate of which they make add-on purchases with things like lower margin hardware. Otherwise, everything we are tracking for Health Services is at or ahead of our expectations.
Now quickly go through the total revenue composition for Q2. Total system sales revenue was $315 million. Support and maintenance was $255 million. Services was $538 million. And reimbursed travel was $18 million.
System sales revenue reflects a 34% increase over Q2 of '14 with the growth mainly driven by an increase in subscriptions which is where the addition of Health Services has had the biggest impact as the list the growth in licensed software.
Our system sales margin percentage was 64.3% which is down slightly from 65.3% in Q2 of '14 and 64.7% in Q1. The decline was driven by lower tech resale margins.
Moving to services. Total services revenue, including professional and managed services, was up 30% compared to Q2 of '14 mainly driven by the addition of Health Services as well as growth in core Cerner Managed Services.
Supported maintenance revenue increased 45% over Q2 of '14, reflecting solid growth in core support and maintenance and the addition of Health Services. Looking at revenue by geographic segment. Domestic revenue increased 30% over the year-ago quarter to $995 million, driven largely by the addition of Health Services. And Global revenue grew 54% to $131 million with core Global revenue being augmented by the addition of Health Services.
Moving to gross margin. Our gross margin for Q2 was 82.9%, which is up from 80.9% in Q2 of '14 with the improved margin reflecting the lower level of third-party services and reimbursed travel.
Looking at operating spending. Our second quarter non-GAAP operating expenses, which exclude share based compensation expense, voluntary separation plan expense and acquisition-related adjustments were $661 million, which is up 37% compared to adjusted Q2 '14 operating expenses. This growth was primarily driven by the addition of Health Services business.
The total year-over-year growth for each expense category on a non-GAAP basis was 32% for sales and client service, 42% for software development, 51% for G&A and 3% decline in amortization as acquisition-related intangibles, which is a new expense line we added this quarter. Note that this line is $25 million on our GAAP income statement and $3 million in our non-GAAP results, since we are excluding amortization related to Health Services.
Moving to operating margins. Our operating margin before share based compensation voluntary separation expense and acquisition-related adjustments was 24.2% in Q2. This is essentially flat compared to Q2 of '14 and up 50 basis points from last quarter. 
Similar to Q1, we achieved our second quarter earnings on lower revenue resulting in a higher operating margin percent than we originally projected. We expect this dynamic to continue for the rest of the year with lower revenues being offset by lower expenses, resulting in no change to our earnings outlook and a higher operating margin percent than we originally projected. We now expect our non-GAAP operating margin for the year to be close to 2014 levels, which compares to the original expectation that we'd go down approximately 200 basis points for the addition of Health Services.
Moving to net earnings and EPS. Our GAAP net earnings in Q2 were $115 million or $0.33 per diluted share. Adjusted net earnings were $183 million, and adjusted EPS was $0.52, which is up 30% compared to Q2 of '14. Adjusted net earnings exclude share-based compensation expense, which had a net impact on GAAP earnings of $14 million dollars or $0.04 per diluted share as well as a voluntary separation plan expense, which had a net impact on GAAP earnings of $28 million or $0.08 per diluted share. Adjusted net earnings also reflect adjustments related to Cerner's acquisition of Health Services, including Health Services acquisition-related amortization, which reduced GAAP net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $14 million and $0.04, respectively; other acquisition related adjustments, which reduced GAAP net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $6 million and $0.01, respectively; and no acquisition related deferred revenue adjustment which is not included in GAAP net earnings but increases adjusted net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $6 million and $0.02, respectively.
The Q2 tax rate for adjusted net earnings was 33%, which is in our expected range of 33% to 34%.
Now move to our balance sheet. We ended Q2 with $857 million of total cash and investments, which is down slightly from $889 million in Q1 due to a negative free cash flow, which I'll discuss in a minute.
The total debt including capital lease obligations was $623 million. Total receivables ended the quarter at $1 billion, which is up $63 million from Q1. Our Q2 DSO was 81 days compared to 79 days in Q1 and 66 days in the year-ago quarter. The higher DSO is primarily a function of the lower revenue in the quarter and some delayed billings for Health Services clients as we transition to our systems. As we move through the year, we expect DSO to come down as revenue increases and we had Health Services billings caught up.
Operating cash flow for the quarter was $109 million, down from $214 million in Q1 due mainly to the voluntary separation plan expense and lower collections related to delayed billings.
Q2 capital expenditures were $85 million and capitalized software was $79 million.
Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow less capital expenditures and capitalized software, is negative $46 million for the quarter driven by a combination of lower operating cash flow and higher capital spending.
Looking ahead, we expect operating cash flow to increase in coming quarters voluntary separation of plan and acquisition-related expenses decline and we improve DSO. Some of the increased operating cash flow will be offset by capital expenditures tied to construction of our new campus and Health Services capital expenditures. We still expect free cash flow to improve initially.
Now go through Q3 and full year 2015 guidance. For Q3, we expect revenue between $1.15 billion and $1. 2 billion, with the midpoint reflecting growth of 40% over Q3 of '14.
For the full year, we expect revenue between $4.475 billion and $4.575 billion, with the midpoint reflecting 33% growth over last year. This is lower than our prior guidance due to lower revenue in Q2 and also factors in the lower year-to-date run rate. 
As I indicated, the lower revenue is not expected to impact our earnings in Q3 -- year. For Q3, we expect adjusted EPS before share-based compensation, voluntary separation plan expense and acquisition-related adjustments to be $0.54 to $0.55 per share, with the midpoint reflecting 30% growth over Q3 '14 adjusted EPS.
For the full year, we expect adjusted EPS before share-based compensation, voluntary separation plan expense and acquisition-related adjustments to be $2.09 to $2.15, which is up from our previous range of $2.07 to $2.15 and reflects 28% growth at the midpoint.
for the impact of share-based compensation expense is approximately $0.03 to $0.04 in Q3 and $0.14 to $0.15 for the full year.
Moving to bookings guidance. We expect bookings revenue in Q3 of $1.35 billion to $1.45 billion, with the midpoint reflecting 27% growth over Q3 of '14.
In summary, while we were disappointed that revenue is below our guidance, we are very pleased with our bookings results and outlook. Importantly, we believe we have appropriately adjusted our revenue guidance to factor in the lower first half revenue and run rate. With that, I'll turn the call over to Zane.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Good afternoon, everyone. Today I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. I'll start with our results.Our bookings revenue in Q2 of $1.29 billion reflects strong growth of 20% over Q2 2014. Bookings this qua
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. Good afternoon, everyone. Today I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. I'll start with our results.
Our bookings revenue in Q2 of $1.29 billion reflects strong growth of 20% over Q2 2014. Bookings this quarter included an all-time high level of large contracts, with 38 contracts over $5 million, including 23 over $10 million. We also had strong contributions from long-term bookings with a large ITWorks contract and an expansion of existing ITWorks relationship. This led to long-term bookings, making up 35% of total, which is a 2% higher than normal.
Demand highlighted the quarter was we signed a record number of new footprints in both in terms of number and dollars. This resulted in 34% of our bookings coming from outside our core Millennium install base. This success reflects our strong competitiveness and the continued large opportunity for competitive displacements. Our wins span many market segments, including IDNs, regional hospitals, children's hospitals, community hospitals, state behavioral health, ambulatory surgery centers and physician groups.
We're also continuing to sign Health Services clients to migrate to Millennium. These clients range from community hospital selecting our CommunityWorks offering to large IDNs. And we continue to see cross-sell activity for solutions like Population Health and ambulatory.
While not part of Q2, I'd like to highlight a significant win for Cerner that was announced today. We were recently selected by Baptist Health South Florida, a leading healthcare organization in the region, to implement Cerner Millennium and Healthe Intent across their 7 hospitals and over 50 outpatient facilities. Baptist Health has recognized us as a national leader in quality, safety and patient satisfaction, and they're looking to Cerner Solutions to optimize the physician experience, improve quality of care and support their efforts to improve patient experience. In addition, they expect to leverage our enterprisewide solutions and Healthe Intent platform to advance their goal to improving care coordination and reducing the cost of care. This recent win, combined with our record level of new footprints in Q2, is evidence of strong momentum we have in the marketplace.
Looking forward, we believe we can build on this momentum, and we remain bullish on new footprint opportunities. Our positive outlook is based on a very large and active pipeline, an all-time high levels of new business activity such as demos, reference calls and visits and Vision Center visits. We continue to believe we have a multiyear opportunity to expand our client base as about half the market is on the legacy system and we think will need to be replaced.
One observation about the buyer in today's market is they're very focused on the predictability of costs and transparency to total cost of ownership. And we believe this is something that plays to our strength. We believe our ability to offer fixed fee pricing on implementations because of our automation tools and implementation methodologies is a competitive differentiator. We also differentiate in our ability to provide services ranging from remote hosting to taking over an entire IT department, which can make our clients total cost much more transparent and predictable. In addition, I believe we have credibility in the industry because of our track record for delivering value. And this credibility is bolstered by our large presence in investor own systems that are known for making ROI base decisions. These clients along with many of our other large IDNs represent some of the largest Healthcare IT deployments in the industry. I think it is worth noting that our ability to deliver value on time and on budget project is a meaningful differentiator relative to our primary competitor, who has a long list of making headline spend a significant cost of deploying and maintaining their system for as a key reason for job loss, financial challenges and debt rating downgrades.
Another marketplace observation is the openness and interoperability and population of health capabilities are becoming more important. This also benefits Cerner because over the long time commitment to interoperability and open standards and our robust Healthe Intent Cloud Platform for Population Health. We continue to expand the presence of Healthe Intent across our client base, and the number of opportunities outside of our base is growing.
Moving to our Revenue Cycle business. We had a good second quarter. All of our new EMR footprints in Q2 included Revenue Cycle, which supports what would have been saying about the market looking to buy integrated systems. Revenue Cycle is an important component of almost all deals in our pipeline. In addition, we are gaining momentum in our existing install base, with several clients selecting us to replace their legacy Revenue Cycle systems in favor of an integrated system. Based on these trends and the growing pipeline for related services, I expect Revenue Cycle to continue contributing to our growth for years to come.
Moving to the ambulatory market, where we had an all-time high level of bookings in Q2. The bookings were driven by success at displacing our key competitors both by expanding our solutions to ambulatory venues of our acute-care clients and as part of new business footprints. In addition, we are continuing to have success selling ambulatory solutions into the Health Services base. Finally, we continue to gain momentum in the ambulatory business office services and expect there to be additional sites where we displace the crowd business office services offering of a certain cloud competitor because of our ability to demonstrate better service and value.
We also had a record bookings quarter in the small hospital market, driven by a combination of traditional new footprints, extensions to our health system clients and Health Services migrations.
Outside of the U.S., we had a good Q2 with total revenue growth of 54%, consisting of good organic growth in the addition of Health Services. The organic growth was primarily driven by strength in the U.K. and the Middle East.
We are also off to a good start at integrating the Global Health Services. We now have a presence in more than 30 countries and believe we are well-positioned for our Global business to be a good contributor to our growth over the next decade. 
Before turning the call over to Mike, I'd like to comment on the recent announcement on the defense healthcare management system modernization project, referred to as in. We are pleased that last week, the Department of Defense announced the decision to award a contract to. As you know the partnership for defense health includes Cerner as the core EHR supplier. We are honored, humbled and excited to be part of a team that won what we believe is the most objective and comprehensive evaluation of technology platforms and solutions ever conducted. We now have the opportunity for Cerner suite of integrated solutions to replace the DoD's legacy health IT systems in its 55 hospitals and more than 350 clinics worldwide, as well as in ships, submarines and in the theater and military operations. We are pleased to be partners with light is some Accenture and Henry Schein and a number of small business partners in making this important transition for our military health system and its 9.6 million beneficiaries. Intermountain Healthcare is also a strategic partner and is providing clinical governance of solutions and workflow.
The partnership is fully prepared to meet the staffing requirements of dim sum and our globally deployed team stands ready to support the DoD and mission. We believe this a positive development for our clients and they should have confidence that Cerner will continue to execute the meet all of our current and future commitments.
As you maybe saw in the announcement, Lighthouse was awarded the contract for $4.3 billion over 10 years consisting of a 2-year initial ordering period, 2 to 3 year option period and another 2-year option period. We're not able to comment on Cerner's portion of this but note that we do not expect this to have a material impact on bookings revenue or earnings in the near term since the project will have several phases and will start with a small initial rollout. I know many of you also saw an $11 billion figure cited in regards to contract before it was announced. As noted in DOD's press release, this estimate is now approximately $9 billion and represents the total estimated program cost over 18 years, not the value of the contract awarded.
In summary, we believe this selection by the Department of Defense reflects positively on the achievement of Cerner, our partners in all our clients. Department of Defense is already in the Cerner family as lab and we're excited to expand our relationship.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks and provide an update on our relationship with the University of Missouri.In the second quarter, we established a new ITWorks relationship and also expanded an existing ITWorks
componenttext:
Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks and provide an update on our relationship with the University of Missouri.
In the second quarter, we established a new ITWorks relationship and also expanded an existing ITWorks relationship. Our new ITWorks client is Catholic Health Initiatives, and this relationship was announced in July. CHI selected ITWorks to improve continuity of care across 47 hospitals and multiple clinic settings. Cerner will assume operational and administrative responsibilities for CHS' IT and facilities in multiple states that use Cerner Millennium. This will include current and future implementations, upgrades, enhancements, optimization, application and operational management and support of the system and clinical service desk support.
CHI has been a client for more than 12 years and this will tighten our alignment and support of CHI station of pioneering models to enhance patient care, safety and clinical outcomes. The alignment will help accelerate the implementation of the latest technology advances available.
The second ITWorks agreement I'd like to discuss is the expansion of our relationship with the University of Missouri Healthcare. MU has been a Cerner client since 1996, and we formed the Tiger Institute for health innovation with them in 2009. Tiger Institute has produced a number of innovations to transform the delivery of care. Examples include technology, integrating calculators into the EHR and developing a consumer-facing mental health app. This year the Tiger Institute launched open notes, a function that gives patients access to the clinical notes through the MU Healthe Patient Portal.
MU Health is also achieve multiple healthcare IT successes, including HIMMS Stage 7, being the first academic medical center to meet Meaningful Use Stage 2 and being designated Most Wired by HNA each of the past 4 years.
Going forward, the Tiger Institute will focus on redefining patient engagement through mobile healthcare, developing a Population Health strategy and network to better position MU Healthcare to lower costs while improving the health of Missourians, increased -- increasing the role of healthcare IT and academic medical research, helping transition to value-based payment model and developing a Tiger Institute value creation office to identify cost savings opportunity. University of Missouri was one of the first ITWorks clients and relationship and we are very pleased with what we've accomplished together as a demonstrates the power of close alignment with our clients.
With that, I'll turn the call over to questions.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

componenttextpreview: Just to start, Marc, as you were talking through the Health Services business, you mentioned that nonrecurring revenue was running a little lower, they're sitting tight, I'm not sure I quite caught the dynamic. Would you mind walking through that?
componenttext: Just to start, Marc, as you were talking through the Health Services business, you mentioned that nonrecurring revenue was running a little lower, they're sitting tight, I'm not sure I quite caught the dynamic. Would you mind walking through that?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. For clients that are not immediately looking to go transition to Cerner Millennium and make the switch, they are not putting in a lot of new solutions from HS into their environment. They're kind of holding back with their hands, that's impacting so
componenttext: Sure. For clients that are not immediately looking to go transition to Cerner Millennium and make the switch, they are not putting in a lot of new solutions from HS into their environment. They're kind of holding back with their hands, that's impacting some of the services that we see normally from HS. It's certainly impacting what their normal hardware and third-party sales would be. So those clients still want to invest in the current infrastructure if they think they're going to switch to Cerner because many of them only switch to Cerner will go to our hosted methodology and they won't need these computers and the hardware that they'd normally be buying. So we expect that as people kind of decide what their timeframe for moving is that we will see that free up and people will [indiscernible] 3-year window or whatever the window is they need to make these purchase and we'll see that start bouncing back. But as we look at that business, the one thing that's lower is the add on type sales into the base that surrounds their existing platform. People kind of waiting to get there go forward decisions before they continue to make those incremental investments.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And my follow-up would be, as you think about the op margin and now that you won't have the 200 basis point impact, how much of that is attributable to mix versus actions that you've taken on expense?
componenttext: That's helpful. And my follow-up would be, as you think about the op margin and now that you won't have the 200 basis point impact, how much of that is attributable to mix versus actions that you've taken on expense?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's a good point. When you look at the results for this quarter, clearly, I think our software -- license software was one of the strongest revenue quarters we ever seen. So that obviously brings with much with the higher-margin, doesn't
componenttext: Well, I think that's a good point. When you look at the results for this quarter, clearly, I think our software -- license software was one of the strongest revenue quarters we ever seen. So that obviously brings with much with the higher-margin, doesn't contribute as much to revenue growth, but it certainly contributes to earnings growth. So I think from a mix perspective, we saw that. We're continuing certainly on the EHS side, lower tech resale elements with lower margin help overall margins, help the revenue so much. But and I think just the activity around the acquisition and thoroughly reviewing not only HS spending but Cerner spending to make sure we're appropriately investing was good for the business. So I think that's overall giving us a little bit of a tailwind from this expense side. So it is a mix to some extent, but there is some real savings on the spending side that we've incurred. Part of it even is on the services business where we are just starting to ramp up hiring now to meet the 2015 bookings demand that we saw in the first half and we expect to see in the second half.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Charles Rhyee with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Charles Rhyee with Cowen and Company.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Marc, first one on the revenue here. Obviously, you talked about less third-party in the quarter than you expected, and now y r going to ramp up the hiring. Was there something that changed that made you realize that you needed to do more of a hiring that
componenttext: Marc, first one on the revenue here. Obviously, you talked about less third-party in the quarter than you expected, and now y r going to ramp up the hiring. Was there something that changed that made you realize that you needed to do more of a hiring that you didn't anticipate earlier? What's sort of the signal to you that we didn't really have enough people for the demand?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we're certainly meeting all of the demand relative to project working implementation work. Part of it was a desire to make sure that we thoroughly had a chance to review all of the HS service resources, decide what was needed to stay in that busin
componenttext: I think we're certainly meeting all of the demand relative to project working implementation work. Part of it was a desire to make sure that we thoroughly had a chance to review all of the HS service resources, decide what was needed to stay in that business, what we could convert to doing Millennium work. I think probably the services business we did in address is much might have been some of the optional nonimplementation work that we often see and often get signed and executed within the quarter. But I think that was prudent as we went through. I think I would certainly take it on these as probably not having the resource element reflected as accurately in our forecasting model as I should have, so a little bit of lower revenue being a little bit lower than guidance is just on that. We've adjusted that going forward. So the rest of the year we feel very confident on the revenue guidance that we provided. But it's not -- it's getting to these new projects as much as it is some of the ancillary service activities we get. And then third party, we really like to minimize how much we use third-party services. We have a lot of Meaningful Use activity in the year-ago quarter, lots of what's going on and that's why you saw the much higher third-party and a much higher travel revenue that came through the P&L.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then as a follow-up, obviously you highlighted Revenue Cycle management as important area. Can you talk about how you feel about your capabilities in this regard internally? Then would you obviously you have a lot of cash in the balanc
componenttext: That's helpful. And then as a follow-up, obviously you highlighted Revenue Cycle management as important area. Can you talk about how you feel about your capabilities in this regard internally? Then would you obviously you have a lot of cash in the balance sheet. Is there any thoughts to deploy that to add to your capacity there, capabilities there?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: From a Revenue Cycle, I think we're very happy with where we are at relative to the solution that we have out there and relative to the certainly the initial RevWorks and Revenue Cycle activities. As we've talked about in the past, we can do anything from
componenttext: From a Revenue Cycle, I think we're very happy with where we are at relative to the solution that we have out there and relative to the certainly the initial RevWorks and Revenue Cycle activities. As we've talked about in the past, we can do anything from a full outsourcing of the Revenue Cycle, which we call RevWorks to business office to just assisting with providing the solutions that is state-of-the-art relative to Revenue Cycle. So as far as deploying our capital and some type of an acquisition that would be in that space, I think we're very happy with where we're at right now. And I think we're doing the normal Cerner strategy of developing, spending our capital on R&D and taking the market share right now kind of a client at a time.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Donald Hooker with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Donald Hooker with KeyBanc.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it seems like this ITWorks business is doing very well. You gave some numbers for last year, did well. It seems like you keep planning nice if there. I keep wondering in my mind whether ITWorks is perhaps somewhat of a leading indicator as well of busi
componenttext: So it seems like this ITWorks business is doing very well. You gave some numbers for last year, did well. It seems like you keep planning nice if there. I keep wondering in my mind whether ITWorks is perhaps somewhat of a leading indicator as well of business for you. Is it the case where people sort of adopt the ITWorks service and then you can really sell more product to them? Or is it a lagging indicator where it's sort of a culmination of a relationship with the client?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Marc. I mean, ITWorks usually tends to be later in the lifecycle of the client. It's really an indicator that the client has decided to go all in that they are going to replace every ancillary system they have. With Cerner, they want to do it as q
componenttext: This is Marc. I mean, ITWorks usually tends to be later in the lifecycle of the client. It's really an indicator that the client has decided to go all in that they are going to replace every ancillary system they have. With Cerner, they want to do it as quickly as possible. They want to do it with people really know how to go operate that environment. That's usually where we see the ITWorks activity occurring. Certainly, as we have more and more experience, more and more clients that we can show as examples of how that's worked, it's getting to be something that our client base is developing a higher level of interest. They want to make sure that they can get their cost manage well and that they can be certainly predictable. And ITWorks makes less of them get make their cost in the IT space highly predictable relative to running their system. So it really is although when we signed up for ITWorks, certainly follow on solutions as they switch out those ancillary as they occur. But that really once they go into ITWorks, there's follow-on business, but that's really almost not necessarily culmination of the relationship. But at that point, we are pretty sticky in their environment and switching from that is very, very difficult. And certainly, we don't give them any reason to want to switch. And certainly, the ITWorks opportunity, we see RevWorks starting to be able to follow in that same line. As we get through ICD-10, we think the desire for remaining systems to get out of the revenue collection business and outsource the revenue cycle is going to continue to build and everything actually when we look at how we grow our revenue in the future, we think those Works businesses are certainly big opportunities because each kind of ITWorks business is at least $7 million to $10 million a year of additional revenue. So and some of them would be more than that. Our pipeline for the next 12 months on the Works business is pretty strong.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then one other one, and then I'll hop off. You all mentioned that you had strong growth in the smaller hospitals segment. I guess I'm thinking here the community works offering. I also heard anecdotes of sort of moving to larger that offering
componenttext: Got you. And then one other one, and then I'll hop off. You all mentioned that you had strong growth in the smaller hospitals segment. I guess I'm thinking here the community works offering. I also heard anecdotes of sort of moving to larger that offering is successfully selling into larger hospital settings. Is that true? Are you getting, seeing more traction of community works sort of in larger hospitals and before or is this still predominantly small hospital?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

componenttext: This is Zane. It's still a predominantly small hospital offering. What we have seen are certain large clients that want to create part of their networks and use the community Works model in some of those critical access connector facilities. So if you've heard about that in some of the larger organizations, it may be part of their feeder systems as they look to create more network in their own areas.

componenttext: This is Zane. Clearly, our clients are actually very excited for the win. We've a lot of very positive momentum from them. And really, I do expect it to have a positive impact as we look forward to some of the competitive environment. As you look at where we come out of Q2 with our best win rate, with the highest number of new footprints in our history and then you add to that the selection by the DoD and our announcement today on Baptist South Florida, you get a flavor for what's happening in the marketplace, that the momentum is clearly on our side. And so I do think that's a big positive.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

componenttext: Michael, this is Marc. I think, certainly, it is pretty near term, but we have a lot of momentum going. This merely continues that strong momentum. I think certainly it was a process that was more rigorous than any you've ever seen and to win is a big accomplishment. Now I think as you look at our Q3 bookings guidance, which is up significantly, you're seeing not only our existing momentum but our belief that this will help us close business as soon as Q3.

componenttext: No. We're using the same approach. It's just a lot of the deal makes just happen to have more of the 10-year deals as a component of it relative to the kind of traditional 30% or so that we've seen in the past. It comes and goes depending on what [indiscernible]

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Halper.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if you think about the revenue miss from the first quarter and you have the second revenue disappointment this year. And so now you're telling us that you sort of scrub those numbers and now the guidance is you feel really confident in that. But could
componenttext: So if you think about the revenue miss from the first quarter and you have the second revenue disappointment this year. And so now you're telling us that you sort of scrub those numbers and now the guidance is you feel really confident in that. But could you sort of tell us what didn't happen or what changed from one quarter to the next? Just trying to understand the what the work here.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, and it's a great question. Clearly, as we went into Q2 and prepared to talk to you guys last time, services is primarily the focus for us relative from a revenue perspective. License software is doing well. Other elements are doing well. We are see
componenttext: Steve, and it's a great question. Clearly, as we went into Q2 and prepared to talk to you guys last time, services is primarily the focus for us relative from a revenue perspective. License software is doing well. Other elements are doing well. We are seeing some lower third -- lower tech resale from certainly from HS and a little bit from us, which is impacting the revenue. But the lion's share of it is related to services. Some of that is as I indicated, as we went through in more detail this quarter and reviewed our forecasting process, I think we were -- there were some something in those forecast that gave us a bigger number than it should have. And that included -- including more third-party. Because third-party is something we have a little hard time getting visibility to because it's not necessarily -- it's coming out of backlog, it's not necessarily that's coming in out of our resources, so it's a little bit of a different model. So I think services clearly missed their forecast in this period. And I think just in the quarter, there is a couple of deals that had some would have contributed some decent size revenue to the quarter for not necessarily high-margin revenue, but some revenue that didn't happen in the quarter that we would have forecasted from a revenue perspective. But at this point, I think there's nothing in the business that is causing us to miss our guidance. I think it's more of the guidance was probably higher than it should've been when we went into last quarter. We've now adjusted it. I feel very confident, as you know. And you could expect, beat this really hard since we closed the quarter and prior to that to understand it well. And I'm pretty confident that we've got good numbers out there for you going forward and pretty confident that services business bounces back as we continue to ride the momentum in '15 and to services personnel and how that pipeline of works businesses we think will contribute pretty significantly likely to the to '16 number. So definitely my bad on the guidance variance today, but I'm not going to have that in my bag next quarter.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And CapEx expectation for the rest of the year around the new campus?
componenttext: Okay. And CapEx expectation for the rest of the year around the new campus?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, as we go forward, you're going to see us obviously spending more than we did [indiscernible], Steve, on the cash flow. You see us having periods where we invested capital heavily. So go back to 2012, we had 100%. We delivered free cash flow a
componenttext: Yes. I mean, as we go forward, you're going to see us obviously spending more than we did [indiscernible], Steve, on the cash flow. You see us having periods where we invested capital heavily. So go back to 2012, we had 100%. We delivered free cash flow at 100% net income. In '13, we bumped up cap CapEx significantly, and that went down to 34%. Last year, we had less CapEx. This year we're going to have a strong CapEx. So kind of looking at building CapEx as price somewhere in the $150 million range. So it would be pretty strong. And our other capital expenditures, including HS, will be up from last year. But as we roll forward, and we get that campus -- the first phase of the campus completed, you should see us starting to bounce back from a free cash flow perspective. We got hit pretty hard this quarter from just a working capital perspective and probably $100 million of working capital on the balance sheet went negative relative to operating cash flow. That will reverse as we go [indiscernible] some business my expectation is we will forward in '16 and '17, you see us getting working getting closer to get into our goal of net income equaling free cash flow.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

componenttext: And what was the 1 50 number that you just put out there?

componenttext: That was basically building CapEx, kind of rough estimate of what we would probably spend. Because right now the last half of this year would be pretty intensive investment relative to our buildings.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Hill with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Hill with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Marc, I think I'm going to want to drill into the services revenue shortfall in a little bit more, too. If we look at kind of from where the guidance originally came out in February where we are now, it's almost $0.5 billion negative revision at the reven
componenttext: Marc, I think I'm going to want to drill into the services revenue shortfall in a little bit more, too. If we look at kind of from where the guidance originally came out in February where we are now, it's almost $0.5 billion negative revision at the revenue line. Can you talk to us a little bit more about where those services revenues lines kind of get sprinkled on the income statement? Is any of it in system sales? Is it all just in that services sub line, under support maintenance and services? And then if a lot of this is tied to third parties, I mean, that seems like a real big movement relative to the size of what we expected the income statement line there to look like for the year. I guess, can you give us some examples functionally of what's going on, it's kind of I mean pushing that line around in a pretty significant direction?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, have to do math on the $0.5 billion number. But I think the key is relative to -- compared to the year-ago quarter when we had a bunch of third parties getting to Meaningful Use projects that we are not doing that as much, that is harder for us to fo
componenttext: Yes, have to do math on the $0.5 billion number. But I think the key is relative to -- compared to the year-ago quarter when we had a bunch of third parties getting to Meaningful Use projects that we are not doing that as much, that is harder for us to forecast and we did not do a job of putting into our forecast the significantly reduced number. So that's what was probably $20 million in the year-ago quarter that we are lower than that this quarter. So that's a pretty big change relative to the total. I think part of the difference you talked about when you're going back to the revenue line, you're getting going back to last quarter where we  talked about the Health Services deferred revenue, it was about $100 million. So there's other elements than just services, if you're going to kind of step back for revenue discussions we've had in the last 12 months. But from a services perspective, key for us is forecasting accurately based on our backlog. It's got to be delivered in the resource we have available to go deliver that. And we did not do that effectively in Q2 as we should have. We've now gone through that forecast with a finetooth comb. So from a business perspective, it's pretty logical that with less third party, revenues not going to be there but then delivered a services from our own personnel and we are adding to that personnel line everyday, certainly with a lot of the college hires coming out of school that will hit us basically Q2, Q3. Those are the resources we need to go out and deliver the work that Zane and his team are delivering for us. So that will drive out the revenue that we've got projected. We're up against a very difficult comp relative to 2014 where we grew revenue 17%. So you got to back of your mind keep that present because when you just look at the 2 years, we still are growing revenue relatively good on average. In addition, as we roll into next year, because of what we see or what I see in the opportunities from the works businesses and as we ramp up the services opportunities from a delivery perspective, I don't -- we should still be talking about being able to deliver double-digit growth in 2016. Obviously, it's early to talk about that. We haven't given any guidance to that. But I believe it is laying out in a way that some of these works deals could be a significant tailwind for us to get that double-digit revenue growth.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe ask another way, it sounds like there's a capacity issue that de you guys do you not have the service capacity to kind of. . .
componenttext: Okay. Maybe ask another way, it sounds like there's a capacity issue that de you guys do you not have the service capacity to kind of. . .

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. We have plenty of to address to work. The keys implementation work that we're working on primarily now is that which was signed in 2014. We've seen a lot more activity in 2015 but we're ramping up so when those projects get to the point they need to b
componenttext: No. We have plenty of to address to work. The keys implementation work that we're working on primarily now is that which was signed in 2014. We've seen a lot more activity in 2015 but we're ramping up so when those projects get to the point they need to be sources we're absolutely ready to go to deliver those. But from a revenue standpoint, because of preparing for HS being very careful about over hiring, there are certain optional services elements that are not related to implementation that we didn't necessarily go after that work, it's certainly going to be there. We can at a later time but we wanted to make sure that we didn't hire a bunch of people relative to the work that's going to be able to be out there. When you look at services for me also have a little bit of an HS element that just because of the transition that they're not as efficient as we would normally have our services people be from the availability standpoint. So those are all factored into it. At this point, I think we've got the right number out there. We feel very confident in it. We are delivering on projects as believe we should be delivering and we are not resource-constrained relative to the business.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Daniels with William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Daniels with William Blair.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Jeff in for Ryan. I wanted to ask about the better profitability. Previously you've talked about margins declining this year because of Health Services, but now they're looking flattish year-over-year. So does that mean we should expect less of a lif
componenttext: It's Jeff in for Ryan. I wanted to ask about the better profitability. Previously you've talked about margins declining this year because of Health Services, but now they're looking flattish year-over-year. So does that mean we should expect less of a lift in 2016? Or should intermediate-term margin target be moving up?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think at this point, you probably need to digest and obviously when we get to Q3, we'll give you our kind of our first view of what 2016 looks like. Certainly, we like the fact that our margins are trending higher, that we didn't have the negative
componenttext: Yes, I think at this point, you probably need to digest and obviously when we get to Q3, we'll give you our kind of our first view of what 2016 looks like. Certainly, we like the fact that our margins are trending higher, that we didn't have the negative that we anticipated with Health Services. But I think relative to '16, it's a little early for us to give you a good view as to what that number is going to be. Our expectation, obviously, with Health Services was that once we kind of step the baseline, that we would be migrating them toward our margins, which should allow for margin improvement. So that would be my expectation. But at this point, it's a little to be quantify.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's fair. And then just to follow up on that though it does seem like on the expense side of things, both in terms of Health Services and Cerner, you're doing well to take a close look at the business and manage those expenses. And how does that offset
componenttext: That's fair. And then just to follow up on that though it does seem like on the expense side of things, both in terms of Health Services and Cerner, you're doing well to take a close look at the business and manage those expenses. And how does that offset potential shifts in the business mix where maybe some of these services are going to come back in 2016 and the works businesses, how those are going to mix in with the rest of the business model and if there's anything from an accounting perspective that we should think about in terms of longer-term margin, that would be helpful as well.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Most of the hiring that you could expect us to do will be on people that are providing -- that are revenue producing. And for the most part, our services businesses have contribution margin in excess of 30%. So that given our current operating margin
componenttext: Yes. Most of the hiring that you could expect us to do will be on people that are providing -- that are revenue producing. And for the most part, our services businesses have contribution margin in excess of 30%. So that given our current operating margins, those people coming on and delivering revenue is going to be accretive to our operating margins. So I think that when we see us increasing spending, it will be revenue-producing areas. The works businesses are a little bit unique in that for the most part, I'm taking over an existing workforce. So I don't have to ramp up internally my resources to be able to handle that work. For the most part, you bring in a team that is already doing that work and I have a core group of people in Cerner that can add some of that initial initiation of that client as part of their normal workflow. So that's easier from a resourcing perspective because once they come on, there are instantly workforce in place into revenue and expenses driven immediately without having to for us to do any resourcing.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Gillmor with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Gillmor with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick clarifications. Marc, you provided some commentary around the DSO trends. Can you maybe give us a little more detail on the delayed billings you mentioned. And also the anticipate DSOs can get back down to the mid-60 range or should
componenttext: Just a couple of quick clarifications. Marc, you provided some commentary around the DSO trends. Can you maybe give us a little more detail on the delayed billings you mentioned. And also the anticipate DSOs can get back down to the mid-60 range or should we be thinking about a higher long-term target?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the key for just on the billings was the hardest part for some of the acquisition work is getting billed out to the clients, to make sure the bills are right, make then get paid. I think if you look at our receivables, you'll see that there w
componenttext: Yes. I think the key for just on the billings was the hardest part for some of the acquisition work is getting billed out to the clients, to make sure the bills are right, make then get paid. I think if you look at our receivables, you'll see that there were pretty significant increase in those receivables. So I think we did a good job as we closed out Q2 of getting bills out. So you got to get the bills out before you start getting paid. So that was the key focus for us. And now that those bills are slowing, then we should start seeing the cash come in and that will impact the receivables by reducing it, which obviously will help our DSO number. As far as what is the optimum DSO number, 66 days is a pretty -- when you're selling into healthcare, which is a traditionally slow pay industry, 66 days is a pretty low number. I'm not wanting to say that, that's not the number that we should be targeting and shooting for. But we'll certainly be looking at it carefully as we go forward. And once we start getting the trend down, we should get a better view as to -- if there should be a different expectation of getting down to that. But I think taking things from around 70 is probably a pretty good target for us to be shooting for.

componenttext: Okay. Great. And then I just wanted to add one follow-up on the DOD contract. And I know you haven't provided lot of details around this,  understand the sensitivity. headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So most of my questions have been asked, but just want to get a little more detail surrounding the better margin performance and context of the synergies from the HS transaction thus far. I'm understand the mix component but just wanted to get a sense of
componenttext: So most of my questions have been asked, but just want to get a little more detail surrounding the better margin performance and context of the synergies from the HS transaction thus far. I'm understand the mix component but just wanted to get a sense of our weeks pulling forward synergies which are driving better margins? Or the synergies tracking as expected and we should think about that building as previously communicated through 2017?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think our prior communication relative to we think HS does in 2017 is still on track. I don't know, as I said, HS is doing a good job of delivering just based on our expectations except for the add-on sales into the base. So I think they are on tra
componenttext: Yes. I think our prior communication relative to we think HS does in 2017 is still on track. I don't know, as I said, HS is doing a good job of delivering just based on our expectations except for the add-on sales into the base. So I think they are on track, and we would expect them to deliver the 2017 synergies that we discussed.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then my last question will be in terms of the growth R&D spend. Obviously, you guys spend a lot of money, when you factor in kind of capitalized development cost and things along those lines. Wanted to get a sense of how you guys measure return on tha
componenttext: And then my last question will be in terms of the growth R&D spend. Obviously, you guys spend a lot of money, when you factor in kind of capitalized development cost and things along those lines. Wanted to get a sense of how you guys measure return on that investment certainly as it's ballooned over the years and it's paying dividends are very strong bookings growth. But wanted to get a better sense of your ultimate of you on R&D dollars and maybe when we could see that number potentially start to leveled off a little bit to drive faster earnings growth?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Marc. We've -- as we've moved forward certainly over the last 3 and 4 years, we've become even more convinced that acquiring technology is not an effective strategy relative to the complex systems that we're developing. So we have decided we'
componenttext: Yes. This is Marc. We've -- as we've moved forward certainly over the last 3 and 4 years, we've become even more convinced that acquiring technology is not an effective strategy relative to the complex systems that we're developing. So we have decided we're going to invest the dollars that we might spend in acquisitions, invest that in R&D and building the capacity. As a finance guy trying to compute an ROI on broad R&D is someone's got a good way of doing that, let me know, I think for me it's been a matter of faith but we need to invest in it. We certainly have a rigorous process by which we examine hundreds of projects and then decide which one of them is going to get the resourcing to get the done. And a component of that is the expected economic return we think that, that's going to drive. So there is an ROI component. But I think we have -- our strategy so far has proven very effective to build it ourselves, to incorporate into the Millennium Healthe Intent platform, and that's probably more of a focus of ours than deciding based on these projects what the ROI is. It's such a big view of the world we have relative to R&D that trying to segment out single solutions would be a difficult thing.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just look at this and say I think we see so much opportunity out there in the future that we're going to see us continue to invest in R&D and develop solutions because the future outlook is incredibly bright. And as we look forward, we're continui
componenttext: I would just look at this and say I think we see so much opportunity out there in the future that we're going to see us continue to invest in R&D and develop solutions because the future outlook is incredibly bright. And as we look forward, we're continuing to invest for the future of the company and we'll continue to make those investments.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that being said, certainly, we're investing a lot of money in R&D. And it would be logical to me that the increase in R&D spend grows at a slower rate than the growth of revenue. So they should be based on the size of that number leverage in the futur
componenttext: And that being said, certainly, we're investing a lot of money in R&D. And it would be logical to me that the increase in R&D spend grows at a slower rate than the growth of revenue. So they should be based on the size of that number leverage in the future. But we are, right now, in an environment where we are highly competitive, lots of business activity and we're going to invest to meet opportunity.

componenttext: Just an easy one. You may have already touched on this and I missed it, but we've seen the longer-term portion of bookings elevated for a couple of quarters here. I mean, should we view kind of the mid-30s range as kind of the new reality? You guys have a good opportunity on the works front, not only I would assume within your customer base but the Siemens base as well. You're obviously looking for a very healthy bookings number in the third quarter. Could you just touch on that, please?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean it's still is pretty quarter dependent and a lot of it's driven by large work steel that's going to occur. So I think that when we talk about can we get to a point where we got a good size works deal every quarter on a pretty consistent basis?
componenttext:
Yes. I mean it's still is pretty quarter dependent and a lot of it's driven by large work steel that's going to occur. So I think that when we talk about can we get to a point where we got a good size works deal every quarter on a pretty consistent basis? We've got to that point, we'd be given the mid-30s relative to percent from long-term. I expect our non long-term bookings to continue to grow as well. So I don't know that I'm going to point where I think 35% is the number that is going to be the standard going forward. I'd see what the percentage in Q3 and then we'll revisit that.
I want to thank everyone for joining the call today. We appreciate your attendance, and we look forward to talking to you in the next days and months. Thanks for your attention. Bye-bye.
