headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Third Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Today's date is November 3, 2015, and this call is being recorded. The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements includ
componenttext:
Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Third Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Today's date is November 3, 2015, and this call is being recorded. The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements including without limitation those regarding projections of future revenues or earnings, operating margins, operating expenses, product development, new markets or prospects from the company solutions and plans and expectations related to the Health Services business and other client achievements. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by the forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements may be found under Item 1A in Cerner's Form 10-K together with the company's other filing.
A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed in this earnings call can be found in the company's earnings release, which was furnished to the SEC today and posted on the investor section of cerner.com.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Marc Naughton, Chief Financial Officer of Cerner Corporation.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bridget. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call. I'll lead off today with a review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with the results highlights and marketplace observations. Neal Patterson, our Chairman and C
componenttext:
Thank you, Bridget. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call. I'll lead off today with a review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with the results highlights and marketplace observations. Neal Patterson, our Chairman and CEO will be available for Q&A. Now I'll turn to our results.
Similar to recent quarters, our great success in the marketplace is reflected in our record bookings, but we delivered revenues slightly below expectations. Today, we'll address the disconnect between our outstanding bookings and what remains a very strong marketplace and our near-term revenue shortfalls. While we are disappointed about delivering slightly lower-than-expected revenue, our bookings this year, coupled with our strong pipeline, sets us up for good revenue growth next year.
Our bookings revenue in Q3 was $1.59 billion, which is an all-time high and reflects 44% growth over Q3 of '14, including record amounts of new business activity. Our revenue backlog ended the quarter at $13.9 billion, which is up $10.2 billion -- from $10.2 billion a year ago and reflects the strong bookings in Q3 as well as the inclusion of backlog from Health Services.
Revenue in the quarter was $1.13 billion, which is up 34% over Q3 of '14 and includes approximately $250 million from Health Services. The total is about $20 million below the low end of our guidance range, with approximately half of the shortfall related to core Cerner and half attributable to Health Services.
On the Cerner side, the shortfall is much lower than previous quarters mainly because we appropriately adjusted our forecast for lower services revenue, which is the primary issue in prior quarters. This quarter, the lower-than-expected revenues is mostly a function of lower-than-usual levels of upfront software revenue on some of our larger contracts and technology resale being slightly below our expectations.
On the software portion, I'd like to note that we had an all-time high level of software bookings but a larger-than-normal portion of the contract was structured in a manner that resulted in the revenue being spread over a longer period. This is obviously good for future periods but did impact our current quarter revenue.
Relative to Health Services, the lower revenue was spread among a few areas, including software, technology resale and maintenance revenue and also reflects that we're continuing to fine tune our visibility in that space.
Another factor we have not discussed that has impacted revenue this year is foreign currency fluctuations. In Q3, revenue would have been $20 million higher if you held exchange rates consistent with those in Q3 of '14. While we have factored a portion of this into our guidance, it did have some impact beyond what we expected in Q3 and is also a contributor to the lower revenue for the year.
Now I'll quickly go through the total revenue composition for Q3. Total system sales revenue was $325 million, support and maintenance was $245 million, services was $539 million and reimbursed travel was $19 million.
System sales revenue reflects a 45% increase over Q3 of '14 with the growth mainly driven by an increase in subscriptions, which is where the addition of Health Services has had the biggest impact as well as growth in licensed software and tech resale.
Our software sales margin percent was 67.5%, which is up from 64.3% in Q2 due to sequential decline in technology resale. The margin percentage is down year-over-year mainly because Q3 '14 had a very low mix of tech resale that resulted in unusually high system sales margin percent.
Moving to services. Total services revenue, including professional and managed services was up 30%, compared to Q3 of '14 mainly driven by the addition of Health Services as well as growth in core Cerner managed services.
Support and maintenance revenue increased 38% over Q3 of '14, reflecting growth in core support and maintenance and the addition of Health Services. 
Looking at revenue by geographic segment. Domestic revenue increased 35% over the year-ago quarter to $998 million and Global revenue grew 32% to $130 million, both driven largely by the addition of Health Services.
Moving to gross margin. Our gross margin for Q3 was 83.1%, which is basically flat both year-over-year and sequentially.
Looking at operating spending. Our third quarter non-GAAP operating expenses, which exclude share-based compensation expense, voluntary separation plan expense and acquisition-related adjustments were $661 million, which is up 36% compared to adjusted Q3 '14 operating expenses. This growth was primarily driven by the addition of Health Services business.
The total year-over-year growth for each expense category on a non-GAAP basis was 32% for our sales and client service, 37% for software development and 62% for G&A.
Amortization of acquisition-related intangibles which you recall is a new expense line we added in Q2 was basically flat. Note that similar to last quarter, this line is $25 million on our GAAP income statement and just $3 million in our non-GAAP results since we are excluding amortization related to Health Services.
Moving to operating margins. Similar to the past 2 quarters, we delivered basically in line earnings on lower revenue, resulting in a higher operating margin percent than we projected at the beginning of the year. Our operating margin before share-based compensation expenses, voluntary separation expense and acquisition-related adjustments was 24.5% in Q3. This is down 90 basis points year-over-year due mostly to the very low tech resale in Q3 '14 and up 30 basis points from Q2 of '15.
Moving to net earnings and EPS. Our GAAP net earnings in Q3 were $147 million, or $0.42 per diluted share. Adjusted net earnings were $189 million and adjusted EPS was $0.54, which is up 29% compared to Q3 of '14. Adjusted net earnings exclude share-based compensation expense, which had a net impact on GAAP earnings of $14 million or $0.04 per diluted share as well as a voluntary separation plan expense, which had a net impact on GAAP earnings of $2.5 million or $0.01 per diluted share. Adjusted net earnings also reflect adjustments related to Cerner's acquisition of Health Services, including Health Services acquisition-related amortization, which reduced GAAP net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $15 million and $0.04, respectively. Other acquisition-related adjustments, which reduced GAAP net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $4 million or $0.01, respectively. And the acquisition related deferred revenue adjustment, which is not included in the GAAP net earnings but increased adjusted net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $6 million and $0.02, respectively.
The Q3 tax rate for adjusted net earnings was 32% which is slightly below our expected range of 33% to 34%.
Now I'll move to our balance sheet. We ended Q3 with $766 million of total cash and investments, which is down from $857 million in Q2 primarily due to use of cash for our repurchase programs.
During the quarter, we finished the remaining $100 million of repurchases authorized in 2014 and purchased $100 million of the $245 million authorized in September of this year. In total, we repurchased 3.2 million shares at an average price of $61.91.
Moving to debt. Our total debt, including capital lease obligations, is $631 million, which is basically flat compared to Q2.
Total receivables ended the quarter at $1.05 billion, which is up $50 million from Q2. Our Q3 DSO was 85 days compared to 81 days in Q2 and 67 days in the year-ago quarter. The higher DSO is primarily a function of the lower revenue in the quarter, and we are also still working through some delayed Billings for Health Services clients as part of the transition. We do expect DSO improvement in Q4.
Operating cash flow for the quarter was $272 million, up from $109 million in Q2. q3 capital expenditures were $88 million and capitalized software was $72 million. Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow less capital expenditures and capitalized software, is $111 million for the quarter, driven by strong operating cash flow.
Now I'll go through Q4 and full-year 2016 guidance. For Q4, we expect revenue between $1.15 billion and $1.2 billion, with the midpoint reflecting growth of 27% over Q4 of '14. Our Q4 revenue guidance combined with year-to-date results put a slightly below the low end of previously provided full-year guidance as we have factored in the lower results from Q3 and lower Q4 to reflect a similar run rate.
So far this year, favorable mix of revenue lower expenses and Health Services synergies have allowed us to deliver mostly in line earnings despite our lower revenue. Looking at Q4, we do expect a lower revenue to have some impact on earnings, mainly due to continuing effect of lower services revenue and the impact of lower upfront software on some contracts.
We expect Q4 adjusted EPS before share-based compensation, voluntary separation plan expense and acquisition-related adjustments to be $0.56 to $0.58 per share, with the midpoint reflecting 21% growth over Q4 '14 adjusted EPS. This range is below consensus estimates and slightly below our original plan, but it does get us to the low end of our most recently provided full year guidance. Also the Q4 guidance combined with year-to-date results still reflects strong growth of 26% for the full year.
Our estimate for the impact of share-based compensation expense is approximately $0.03 to $0.04 in Q4, which equates to $0.14 to $0.15 for the full year.
Moving to bookings guidance. We expect bookings revenue in Q4 of $1.45 billion to $1.55 billion, with the midpoint reflecting strong growth of 29% over Q4 '14 and 31% growth for the full year.
Now I'd like to provide initial expectations for 2016. Note that these comments should be viewed as preliminary until we finalize our financial plan and provide more formal guidance when we report fourth quarter results.
We currently expect 2016 revenue to be over $5 billion, which equates to growth of at least 13% on top of what is projected to be approximately 30% growth in 2015. We realized the growth this year benefited from our acquisition and has come in below our original targets, but growing 13% on top of 30% growth year [ph] is still strong. Our 13% target does include the benefit of having 12 months of Health Services revenue in 2016 compared to 11 months in 2015, but that only equates to about 2% of the growth for the year, so our full-year growth target is still double digit even excluding the extra month.
While there are obviously many assumptions that go into projecting future revenue, we do feel positive about our ability to deliver good growth in 2016. A key element to our confidence in 2016 revenues are backlog, which has grown significantly this year due to our record bookings and the addition of Health Services business. This larger backlog translates into better visibility for 2016.
As we look at the rollout of backlog in 2016, we currently expect approximately 75% of our revenue to come from backlog, which is higher-than-historical levels. Another key assumption is we do believe the market opportunity remains strong, which Zane will discuss.
For earnings, we currently expect adjusted diluted earnings per share before share-based compensation and acquisition-related adjustments between $2.30 and $2.40 per share, with the midpoint reflecting 13% growth over 2015 expected results. This range is below the current consensus estimate of $2.52, which was formed in the absence of company guidance. We believe the primary potential differences between our preliminary view and the consensus estimate may include higher noncash expenses and professional services contributions.
Regarding noncash expenses, our current estimates reflect an increase in depreciation and amortization of more than $75 million in 2016  which equates to nearly $0.15 of earnings per share. And we believe consensus estimates have less than this for noncash expense impact. The large increase in amortization is tied to a significant amount previously capitalized software expected to become generally available and a large increase in depreciation is related to recent increased levels of capital spending.
Relative to services contribution, while we expect strong growth in services revenue and earnings contributions next year, the growth will be coming off of the lower 2015 levels we have discussed. We do not intend to these comments to precisely reconcile our preliminary view to analyst estimates but more to provide our thoughts of potential differences.
In summary, realize it has been a challenging year relative to delivering against our revenue expectations. As I indicated, we believe revenue growth will be good next year and we have visibility to this growth, partially driven from the backlog that has benefited from what has been by far the best year of bookings in the history of our company. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Zane and talk about why our bookings are so strong.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. I'll start with our results.Our bookings revenue in Q3 of $1.59 billion reflects strong growth of 44% over Q3 2014. Bookings this qu
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. I'll start with our results.
Our bookings revenue in Q3 of $1.59 billion reflects strong growth of 44% over Q3 2014. Bookings this quarter included another all-time high level of large contracts with 45 contracts over $5 million, including 31 over $10 million. For long-term bookings, we did have 2 ITWorks contract, but the overall mix of long-term bookings was more in the normal range of 31%, which makes the strength of these bookings even more impressive because it wasn't driven by elevated levels of longer-term contracts.
Highlight of the quarter was we again signed a record number of new footprints, with 39% of our bookings coming from outside our core Millennium install base. So far this year, we have signed more new footprints measured by dollars and counter sites than any full year in our history. This success reflects our strong competitiveness and the continued large opportunity for competitive displacements. Our success this quarter and opportunities in our pipeline span many market segments, including IDNs, regional hospitals, children, community hospitals, state and federal, be a real health, ambulatory surgery centers and physician groups.
A particularly noteworthy area of success is large IDNs and in the investor on health systems. In addition to McLaren Health Care selecting Cerner for EHR Revenue Cycle and Population Health, which they announced last month, we also gained another large investor owned health system as a new client during the quarter. In addition, one of our existing investor owned clients chose to move forward with Cerner for an additional 24 sites. These are in addition to Baptist Health South Florida and the Department of Defense, which we talked about on our last call but occurred during the third quarter.
As I mentioned before, I believe a key element of our success is driven by our track record for delivering projects on time and on budget as well as creating measurable value, which aligns well with our clients focus on making ROI-based decisions. This ability to deliver value along with predictable cost and timelines and serves as a differentiator relative to our primary competitor. I believe their list of clients where the significant cost of deploying and maintaining our systems has been cited as a key reason for financial challenges is starting to impact them in the marketplace. This not only differentiates us from the sales process, it ahs also contributed in some of their existing clients switching to Cerner even after having spent 100-plus million dollar on their system.
We're also continuing to sign Health Services clients to migrate to Millennium, including both IDNs and small hospitals. Overall, we remain pleased with our progress with Health Services base with migrations continuing at a good pace.
Now I'd to highlight an important announcement we made during the Cerner Health Conference that represents a major milestone for our HealtheIntent platform. During Neal's keynote address, we announced that Geisinger Health System, a national model for high quality and high value health care decided to use our HealtheIntent Population Health platform to extend their data-driven population health capabilities. Cerner and Geisinger share a core belief that managing the health of population requires access to information outside its traditional healthcare domains, and we are excited to be a strategic part of Geisinger's ability to provide systems level insight to manage population health at scale. This relationship builds on proof of concept projects that started last year where Geisinger leverage HealtheIntent, our system-agnostic near real-time platform that normalizes data to aggregate clinical and financial data from its core EHR and other sources such as its insurance company. We believe this decision makes a clear statement to the market as Geisinger uses our primary competitor for their core EHR and as one of their longest duration and most significant clients. We believe this demonstrates that our capabilities cannot be equaled by a competitor and the HealtheIntent platform is the right platform to support Geisinger's quest for ongoing innovation. I also think this makes clear that our investments in interoperability and open platforms that enable client and third-party innovation are paying off. This a great example of why we believe Cerner's positioned to play a major road as healthcare continues to shift in a fee-for-service model to outcomes-based reimbursement model that incent in keeping people healthy.
Moving to our Revenue Cycle business, we had a good third quarter. We continue to have a high take rate of Revenue Cycle in our new EHR footprints which supports what we've been saying about the market looking to buy integrated systems. A key element of our success in Revenue Cycle has been the increasing number of proof points with our clients. One [indiscernible] example I'd like to share is something from a thank you note, client CFOs and as recently. In the note indicated that in the past year, they had decreased AR days 19%, increased average daily revenue 22% and reduced discharge not final bill days by 33%. These success stories are becoming more common and add to our momentum in the marketplace.
Moving to the ambulatory market where we had an all-time high level of bookings in Q3, surpassing our record we just set in the last quarter. The bookings were driven by success at displacing our key competitors both by expanding our solutions to the ambulatory venues of our acute-care clients and as part of new business footprints.
In the ambulatory business offer services, we had 2 displacements of a certain Cloud competitor. Our opportunity to displace this competitor resulted from their lack of execution, failure to meet the established objectives, rising cost after rates and realization by the client that they ended up needing similar or more staff even though they thought they had outsourced the function of our competitors because they have much of the harder work and complex work to the client.
We also had a strong quarter in the small hospital market and passed the 100 client milestone with our Cloud-based CommunityWorks offering. This quarter's success was again driven by combination of additional new footprints, extensions to our health system clients and Health Services migrations. We expect the CommunityWorks offering to exceed 125 clients by year-end.
In addition, CommunityWorks opened 2 new markets by completing multiple client diversions within stand-alone orthopedic surgical hospitals along with a multisite clinically integrated network in the state of Iowa. We believe there is good market opportunity for Cerner in the small hospital market and are very pleased of our competitiveness in this market.
Outside of the U.S., we had a solid Q3 with revenue growth of 32% and good bookings in Australia, United Kingdom and the Middle East. We continue to make progress with integrating the global components of Health Services, which is augmenting our global presence and positioning us for good long-term contributions from our Global business.
In summary, I'm very pleased with the success we are having in the marketplace and maintain a positive outlook because of our large pipeline, broad solution of services offering and strong competitive position.
With that, I'd like to open the call for questions.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from David Francis from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from David Francis from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Marc or Zane, can you help us understand a little bit more as you talked about at the front of the call the difference between getting revenue and the backlog in the bookings, understood from the last quarter there were several contracts that had some mea
componenttext: Marc or Zane, can you help us understand a little bit more as you talked about at the front of the call the difference between getting revenue and the backlog in the bookings, understood from the last quarter there were several contracts that had some meaningful revenue attached to them that didn't fall into the quarter. I'm just trying to true up the difference there so we can better understand the cadence of bookings and how that translates to revenue in the short-term?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Marc. Relative to license revenue, as we said, record bookings for license software in the quarter, we actually had record license revenue, very strong license revenue. However, it was lower than our projections, primarily because certain co
componenttext: Sure. This is Marc. Relative to license revenue, as we said, record bookings for license software in the quarter, we actually had record license revenue, very strong license revenue. However, it was lower than our projections, primarily because certain contracts have some provisions, especially as we started addressing the new markets for new clients who are coming off of a unsatisfactory relationship where they are looking to kind of hold the new supplier spit the fire a little bit. So we do have those contracts. They will have some payments tied to milestones. Traditionally, as we talked to y'all in the past, most of our payments for license software are date-based and don't impact revenue recognition at all. We have seen some payments being tied to milestones, which is very reasonable for clients to do that in this current environment. Those that tied into a milestone defers that revenue to the milestone occurring. So that revenue goes in the backlog and comes out at a future point in time as part of the project that's getting done. Good for the future, when you go into a quarter and don't see those provisions upfront as an expectation, but they are negotiated as we go forward, it does impact the amount of revenue we take in the initial quarter for particularly those new clients as we are seeing that.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me ask it a different way then. As you look at your initial guidance for 2016 and talking about conversion of the backlog into revenue and what have you, the visibility issues that you guys that had relative to this year, kind of what changes over the
componenttext: Let me ask it a different way then. As you look at your initial guidance for 2016 and talking about conversion of the backlog into revenue and what have you, the visibility issues that you guys that had relative to this year, kind of what changes over the next coming several quarters to give you the kind of confidence that the revenue level that you're looking at, up double digits year-over-year, are achievable relative to your ability to convert out of backlog, and I'll stop there.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No. The key for 2016 when I'm looking at '15 [ph] is the amount of backlog we have and the fact that I am having things such as license software rolling out based on the projection of when the projects as I do hours to be done. Another key factor for
componenttext: Yes. No. The key for 2016 when I'm looking at '15 [ph] is the amount of backlog we have and the fact that I am having things such as license software rolling out based on the projection of when the projects as I do hours to be done. Another key factor for '16 is that really in the last half of '15, particularly in Q3, we saw a strong increase in professional services implementation bookings. And we expect to see that in Q4. That strong increase in those specific bookings is beating the backlog, and those projects will be starting and underway in 2016. From a number of bodies times number of hours perspective, we hired over 200 people into this professional services organization during Q3. So we entered the Q2 [ph] with a larger workforce, which means we'll be able to go work additional hours, drive additional revenue from that backlog that's there. The 75% we referenced is coming -- 2016 revenue being driven from the backlog is the highest percent of revenue for a year that I've seen in my tenure here. Normally, I think reasonably it's kind of been in the low 70s. And all of that, out of this point, should be predictive work that we can drive with available headcount. We're not going to be in an HS mode of trying to decide should we hire, should we not hire. We are back into our mode of seeing the work, hiring the people, getting them back to speed. Unfortunately for us, in '15 the impact of that is going to be in '16.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Robert Jones with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Robert Jones with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess just one follow-up on that, Marc, just so I'm clear. I think last few quarters where the top line might have missed expectations it was really more around services, conversion, obviously, just being slower by nature and then also some weakness in
componenttext: I guess just one follow-up on that, Marc, just so I'm clear. I think last few quarters where the top line might have missed expectations it was really more around services, conversion, obviously, just being slower by nature and then also some weakness in tech resale. Am I understanding it correctly that it's still a component of those 2 things but now in addition to that, there's some longer conversions around your more classic license software sales? Is that the message on this quarter's revenue shortfall?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Let me make sure I'm clear. This quarter, we actually delivered our services number, the number we have projected, we delivered that. The difference in the revenue from external projected from what we shared in our projections to what we delivered was
componenttext: No. Let me make sure I'm clear. This quarter, we actually delivered our services number, the number we have projected, we delivered that. The difference in the revenue from external projected from what we shared in our projections to what we delivered was really focused on 2 things, primarily license software from the Cerner side and from a lower-than-expected tech resale. We had a fairly significant -- couple of significant tech resale deals primarily related to third-party -- the resale of third-party software that we expected to happen in the quarter and they did not happen. One of those actually was changed to be sold by the manufacturer, we'll get some profitability out of that, but we won't get the revenue out of that. So that was the primary driver. On the license side for Cerner, why the license was less than we had projected even though it was strong and at record levels, we have projected even higher levels, those contracts from new clients, we had a few of those that were larger that included milestone-based payments. So the payments for the license are tied to milestones, we can't take the revenue for that license software until the milestone occurs. Relative to service businesses, we actually delivered the services number. That was the number we focused on internally and we actually delivered that. But for Q3, the difference was half at HS, half at the Cerner and on Cerner side it was license software and those 2 tech resale deals that didn't materialize.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Just helpful. Back on the EPS range for next year, assuming your guidance of roughly around $5 billion on the top line, it seems like at least directionally would imply a tougher operating margin year than I think many were thinking. I guess first
componenttext: Got it. Just helpful. Back on the EPS range for next year, assuming your guidance of roughly around $5 billion on the top line, it seems like at least directionally would imply a tougher operating margin year than I think many were thinking. I guess first off, is that accurate? And then secondly, could you maybe just talk about the major components of what might be weighing on margins more than people expected?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you if I do a quick math, I think it basically looks at flat operating margins. I mean, they'll be around 25% if you use a revenue number that's around -- that's $5 billion. And to get to the earnings, I think with HS expected not to grow
componenttext: Well, I think if you if I do a quick math, I think it basically looks at flat operating margins. I mean, they'll be around 25% if you use a revenue number that's around -- that's $5 billion. And to get to the earnings, I think with HS expected not to grow quite as much on the operating margin side clearly because of lower revenue this year has actually gotten almost back to our prior operating margin levels. Next year, it's really the impact of the noncash expenses. I mean, that's a $75 million to $80 million hit that is going to impact my operating margins cash hit but it is additional expense. And so I think if you kind of go map out the numbers, you'll end up with about the same operating margins next year, should be within 30, 40 basis points of kind of what we would end up with this year, which is somewhere around 24.5, somewhere in the 24.5 to 25 range would be my rough math for 2016. So we don't see a decrease. We do see because of the higher noncash spending challenging to grow above that. But I think, clearly, we're continuing to invest in the business and should be able to get to a level where we start getting some getting the leverage back in the business as those increases moderate.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Sean Wieland of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is from Sean Wieland of Piper Jaffray.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first, to confirm, I didn't hear you mention any contribution from DOD in the quarter or for '15 or '16. I want to confirm that, that is the case?
componenttext: So first, to confirm, I didn't hear you mention any contribution from DOD in the quarter or for '15 or '16. I want to confirm that, that is the case?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, once again, as we said, DOD will have a certainly a slow impact on the bookings and a slower impact on the revenue that we recognize. We did have the first past quarter, past quarter number 1, we got our group that's group. We got an order from that.
componenttext: Yes, once again, as we said, DOD will have a certainly a slow impact on the bookings and a slower impact on the revenue that we recognize. We did have the first past quarter, past quarter number 1, we got our group that's group. We got an order from that. But that number was less than 1% of my bookings for the quarter. So once again, those numbers have come in pretty small-ish chunks on kind of just in time basis to some extent. So no contribution in '15 from DOD from either earnings or material bookings. And in '16, we're not relying on DOD to be anything that provides additional uplift over the other business.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one other question on follow-up to Dave's on these milestone payments, what kind of milestone are we talking about? Are we talking about shipping of software? Or are we talking about achieving certain savings metrics or clinical measures? C
componenttext: Okay. And then one other question on follow-up to Dave's on these milestone payments, what kind of milestone are we talking about? Are we talking about shipping of software? Or are we talking about achieving certain savings metrics or clinical measures? Can you just kind of tell us what kind of milestones you're baking in to the contracts?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sean, this is Zane. I think it's more project-related items. So as you think about the projects and where these clients have come from, so they are -- I always describe it as they're getting divorced at the same time they're trying to get remarried. And t
componenttext: Sean, this is Zane. I think it's more project-related items. So as you think about the projects and where these clients have come from, so they are -- I always describe it as they're getting divorced at the same time they're trying to get remarried. And their previous vendor has left them in a very challenging position and has basically failed them to deliver the kinds of solutions that they need long-term. And so when you're in those kind of predicaments, it's oftentimes happens that as their clients getting divorced and their former vendor and getting married to Cerner, they come in with a prenup that looks a little bit different than what we would -- you would typically see. And then as we gain experience with that client and gain the confidence in us to deliver those kinds of things tend to go away in subsequent periods. So when we have the high level of new business bookings that we had in the quarter, there is a higher susceptibility to some of those types of activities impacting our results at the end of the day.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And one milestone could be go-live. That's a pretty standard one that they put in. We are saying we're going to get this done in this type of time frame, and they say well that's great, let's tie a payment to us going live when we expect to go-live.
componenttext: And one milestone could be go-live. That's a pretty standard one that they put in. We are saying we're going to get this done in this type of time frame, and they say well that's great, let's tie a payment to us going live when we expect to go-live.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: What about like performance, like AR days or things like that?
componenttext: What about like performance, like AR days or things like that?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, those aren't milestones. In our view, milestones are really events that occur relative to some payments that are at risk in some form or fashion. We'll have some of those in the contract on occasion usually, it's upside to us. So we get our base pric
componenttext: Yes, those aren't milestones. In our view, milestones are really events that occur relative to some payments that are at risk in some form or fashion. We'll have some of those in the contract on occasion usually, it's upside to us. So we get our base pricing, but kind of the last minute. If  there'll be an element of shared savings, then we'll put into contracts because obviously we want the client wants to see us focused on making them successful and the best way to do that is to have some at risk element. But that doesn't really affect my revenue recognition because any at-risk payment doesn't get recognized until we actually receive the payment, not only do we delivered the should get the payment, but we take a conservative position that I've got to get the check in my hand before we take that revenue. But that's outside kind of what I would call revenue recognition.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think I just I wouldn't necessarily say this is a new trend. I think it's just one of those things that when you end up with a higher level of new business bookings that, that's something that is part of the process. And so I wouldn't necessarily sa
componenttext: And I think I just I wouldn't necessarily say this is a new trend. I think it's just one of those things that when you end up with a higher level of new business bookings that, that's something that is part of the process. And so I wouldn't necessarily say that, that's a new trend element. I think the trend part is the significant bookings, our increase new bookings percentage of it into our business.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Eric Percher of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is from Eric Percher of Barclays.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think I'll come back to the margin question. As we look at this year, you've been able to reduce expenses tremendously, and I know that Health Services was a big part of that. Can I ask you just kind of walk us through as you look at the underlying busi
componenttext: I think I'll come back to the margin question. As we look at this year, you've been able to reduce expenses tremendously, and I know that Health Services was a big part of that. Can I ask you just kind of walk us through as you look at the underlying business and maybe the mix shift, really mix question out into next year, there's obviously some noncash elements, but do you expect that your mix continues to give you the opportunity to drive higher up margin? Or do we -- have we entered a period where up margin and earnings looks much closer to the revenue growth number?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Eric, this is Marc. I don't think we're in a period where we would expect operating margins to kind of stay at the same level. We continue to have opportunities, certainly, on a combined HS and Cerner organization to drive out additional synergies on the
componenttext: Eric, this is Marc. I don't think we're in a period where we would expect operating margins to kind of stay at the same level. We continue to have opportunities, certainly, on a combined HS and Cerner organization to drive out additional synergies on the spin side as well as the operating and revenue side. I think that what you'll see us in 2016 kind of offsetting the impact of significantly higher noncash expense, we will add resources at Cerner as to the extent that they drive revenue, and that's kind of been our philosophy in many times -- many points in time. We've invested heavily in R&D and those types of areas more recently, but I don't think you're going to see a lot of needed additional investment in those areas. You'll see us hiring people to go work on projects, drive revenue and you'll see us hiring for managed services which drives revenue, which drives revenue. So that's really what we're going to focus our dollars on. I think once you kind of get through a period of software turning on and ramping up some of the software amortization, we should get back to time when we you'll start seeing improvements in operating margins. There is no real change in the mix of the business. Software is still really strong, and that strength in software should logically us get through some of this is noncash spending element. You should actually get to a point where operating margins can increase.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And the services investments you made, you talked about 200 additional paying members. Does that same type of ramp occur in Q4?
componenttext: That's helpful. And the services investments you made, you talked about 200 additional paying members. Does that same type of ramp occur in Q4?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We can give you the Q4 numbers once we have them. I think the hiring in Q2 or Q3 was related to the Q3 strong bookings that we expected. So I think we will be hiring based on our demand. I would expect to see that number go up. I don't -- I can't tell you
componenttext: We can give you the Q4 numbers once we have them. I think the hiring in Q2 or Q3 was related to the Q3 strong bookings that we expected. So I think we will be hiring based on our demand. I would expect to see that number go up. I don't -- I can't tell you, there's a little bit of hiring at the end of the year in timing relative to when people graduate school and all of this kind of stuff that impacts a lot of people we don't bring until January. So will we at the end of Q3 have another 200 people -- or Q4 have another 200 people, I can't address that but I can indicate that we are back on track to increasing that workforce.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from David Larsen with Leerink Partners.
componenttext: Our next question is from David Larsen with Leerink Partners.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about Siemens Health Services and I guess the revenue came in slightly below expectations. Was that from Siemens hospitals buying other Siemens software solutions? Or was it conversions over to Millennium networks slightly below expectations?
componenttext: Can you talk about Siemens Health Services and I guess the revenue came in slightly below expectations. Was that from Siemens hospitals buying other Siemens software solutions? Or was it conversions over to Millennium networks slightly below expectations? Anymore color on that would be helpful.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dave, this is Marc. The HS was really not related to selling more Siemens software because we aren't expecting to sell a lot of additional Siemens software. Specifically migrations are doing well. So it's primarily just related to their business of
componenttext: Sure, Dave, this is Marc. The HS was really not related to selling more Siemens software because we aren't expecting to sell a lot of additional Siemens software. Specifically migrations are doing well. So it's primarily just related to their business of overall, some maintenance contracts that people canceled was probably big an impact on revenue if anything. Those are dependent on that client having certain equipment or keeping that maintenance contract with Siemens but didn't reflect really major change, it's just the expiration of certain maintenance. And in some cases, people just not renewing their maintenance contracts relative to the equipment that they have through Siemens. The rest of it was just kind of spread throughout the piece of the organization, but nothing that was reflecting a trend relative to their selling more of the Siemens software, which we didn't expect and they didn't do while migrations which are going well and once again fall into a bucket that is not necessarily -- we can necessarily attribute to Siemens because we are selling the revenue. I think we're still working obviously to the visibility on the revenue side. But when we kind of look at the net impact on Cerner, our overall accretion remains on track. It's my primarily at this point just the top line forecasting element timing and we try to get through.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's a great. And then can you sort of size how much bookings in the quarter came from the Siemens side of the house?
componenttext: Okay. That's a great. And then can you sort of size how much bookings in the quarter came from the Siemens side of the house?

componenttextpreview: It would be minimal.
componenttext: It would be minimal.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Minimal, so that was all mainly. . .
componenttext: Minimal, so that was all mainly. . .

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. We would have had a number of migrations that would impact the bookings, but the pure Health Services purchasing Health Services solutions would have been fairly minimal.
componenttext: This is Zane. We would have had a number of migrations that would impact the bookings, but the pure Health Services purchasing Health Services solutions would have been fairly minimal.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: David, we kind of get into the element of what we've been talking to you about is we're kind of one company now. And so anything that we sell that's Cerner stuff, we kind of think of it as Cerner bookings. But even if it's a migration to Cerner from a Sie
componenttext: David, we kind of get into the element of what we've been talking to you about is we're kind of one company now. And so anything that we sell that's Cerner stuff, we kind of think of it as Cerner bookings. But even if it's a migration to Cerner from a Siemens client. So the cross-sell in those elements are going to be coming through our Cerner bookings. The HS bookings for me is primarily things that they're selling into services or their own software. And as I said, we haven't really been focused on selling a lot of their own software at this point.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just one last one. I think you had a couple of large service engagements last quarter. Should we see the revenue flow through for those in 2016?
componenttext: Okay. Just one last one. I think you had a couple of large service engagements last quarter. Should we see the revenue flow through for those in 2016?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean especially relative to our ITWorks business, we've actually had a very successful 2015. We signed 2 ITWorks deals each quarter in Q1, Q2 and Q3. So those are -- that's kind of the revenue that was talked about, wanting to achieve. And once we
componenttext: Sure. I mean especially relative to our ITWorks business, we've actually had a very successful 2015. We signed 2 ITWorks deals each quarter in Q1, Q2 and Q3. So those are -- that's kind of the revenue that was talked about, wanting to achieve. And once we get those signed, that revenue stream you'll start to very quickly because those associates get very close to the timing of the signing of the contract. So that revenue does kick in and all 6 of those deals will be contributing to 2016 revenue.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mohan Naidu with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mohan Naidu with Oppenheimer.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Marc, maybe just when I go back to your bookings and revenue conversion one more time, with your new guidance, it looks like you're going to do 30% plus growth for the full 2015. That's great. But your revenue guidance for next year points to low teens gr
componenttext: Marc, maybe just when I go back to your bookings and revenue conversion one more time, with your new guidance, it looks like you're going to do 30% plus growth for the full 2015. That's great. But your revenue guidance for next year points to low teens growth. Can you help us understand what are the moving parts that translates from a 30% bookings growth to a teens revenue growth?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well certainly, the elements of bookings growing significantly. And keep in mind, in 2015, we are growing revenue 30%, we're growing earnings 26%. Obviously, you understand there's an element from the acquisition that impact that. But when you look at our
componenttext: Well certainly, the elements of bookings growing significantly. And keep in mind, in 2015, we are growing revenue 30%, we're growing earnings 26%. Obviously, you understand there's an element from the acquisition that impact that. But when you look at our bookings, you got the long-term component of them, which this quarter, even on a larger number trended down -- tends to be more normal like the 31% rather than the mid-30s that we've been seeing. That longer-term bookings don't have an immediate effect. They spread out over a period of time. They will help '16, but 1/10 of them helps '16. Relative to current quarters, the item we're talking about primarily was license component, and this is you're talking about $10 million or $15 million of license software when you're talking about that relative to the overall total revenue growth. So it's not a significant difference. A lot of these contracts have significant amount of professional services in them that rolls out over a period of time, sometimes multiyear period of time. They all have hosting element to them, which falls into our long-term bookings percentage. So really, the mix of the business is actually pretty much normalized in Q3. The big difference is even with strong license, based on that bigger number, we weren't -- we did not get much revenue from the current quarter as we would've expected that revenue falls forward. But I think from a growth perspective, if you look at 13% plus revenue growth in 2016 off of a number that grew 30% in 2015, we've got an extra $1 billion or so of revenue that we are growing on top of. We've always targeted growing double digits, especially after a year that was more challenging for us in '15. We're actually pretty feeling good about getting back to double-digit growth on a much higher base than we have had in the past. So we actually think this -- the growth in earnings and the growth in revenue being more aligned than normal is a matter of just not getting as much leverage in 2016 because of higher noncash expense. And I think that, as I said, moderates over time.

componenttext: Got it. That was very helpful. If I understand correct way, if we take out the Health Services revenue out of your 2015 and keep the bookings the same, we could have seen 25% plus revenue growth. Is that fair?

componenttext: You would have certainly seen strong -- you would have seen in '16 stronger revenue growth, absolutely.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Steven Valiquette with UBS.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jonathan on for Steve today. Just a question back on the margins. I to the noncash expense side of things. But I guess from the synergy targets that you originally laid out for the Siemens still, of the $175 million, are you guys still on track fo
componenttext: This is Jonathan on for Steve today. Just a question back on the margins. I to the noncash expense side of things. But I guess from the synergy targets that you originally laid out for the Siemens still, of the $175 million, are you guys still on track for that? Is there a way -- are you guys speeding up kind of just get a sense of where you guys are in terms of the synergy level there?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Relative to Siemens, we are absolutely on track for 2015 delivering the synergies that we expected. We might be slightly ahead, but things are going well there. I think in '16, we continue to expect to deliver the synergies we've originally expected.
componenttext: Yes. Relative to Siemens, we are absolutely on track for 2015 delivering the synergies that we expected. We might be slightly ahead, but things are going well there. I think in '16, we continue to expect to deliver the synergies we've originally expected. As we've indicated, the harder part for us now is because of the coming together of the organizations and the fact that there's some spending on Cerner side that relates to the HS business, it is not plainly that I could give you a P&L for HS. I don't have that visibility. I can't track the spending at that level. And so I can't specifically tell you the exact numbers that it's driving out as a separate P&L. But based on all the metrics that we track, based on their spend, based on our spend, we see that those synergies are coming through. And that is part of the benefit we get on the expense side in '16. So it does help offset some of the noncash. But we're also growing -- we're continuing to invest in revenue-producing associates, which should drive revenue but also is going to drive up spending as well.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the RevWorks side, passed ICD-10 now and hopefully things are good in the market there. Have you guys had heard any chatter about clients particularly looking at your RevWorks solutions yet?
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the RevWorks side, passed ICD-10 now and hopefully things are good in the market there. Have you guys had heard any chatter about clients particularly looking at your RevWorks solutions yet?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. I think we continue see interest in Revenue Cycle in particular, and then obviously the business offers services perspective has been very strong in the physician side. So we continue to see good growth there. I think that you will see a ret
componenttext: This is Zane. I think we continue see interest in Revenue Cycle in particular, and then obviously the business offers services perspective has been very strong in the physician side. So we continue to see good growth there. I think that you will see a return to that marketplace for broader RevWorks offerings there. And we continue to sell well as kind of -- as piece parts of that. But I do sense that, that will return to the fold here as people get past ICD-10 and begin to think more long-term about how to best handle their costs in the collections related to changing business models.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Marc, keep in mind, ICD-10 wasn't just flip the switch and okay, all the lights stay green, so we're good. There's -- 30 days later you're going to get -- one of the payers come back and tell you if they agree with the claims, you're going to be t
componenttext: This is Marc, keep in mind, ICD-10 wasn't just flip the switch and okay, all the lights stay green, so we're good. There's -- 30 days later you're going to get -- one of the payers come back and tell you if they agree with the claims, you're going to be tracking all the metrics you track. So even though people were post the technical ICD-10 go-live, there's still a good 6 months as people are going through and looking at making sure that they understand the impact of ICD-10. We look at what their needs are in the case their environment has changed. So I think that demand, as Zane said, I don't think flipping that switch is going to trigger a bunch of demand. I think it would be something you see starting to hit us in 2016.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from George Hill with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: I guess Marc or Zane, can either of you guys tell us what like for like Cerner bookings are and what the growth is looking year-over-year, because I think there's probably some misunderstanding about the composition how this year includes Siemens bookings and last year did not. So like real bookings growth year-to-date isn't actually 32%. What is kind of a like-for-like Cerner bookings growth?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Marc. Like for like actually is Siemens is negligibly impacting us. That mean, they aren't selling a whole lot of stuff. They aren't selling a lot of tech resale. From a booking's perspective, there's not a lot of -- they haven't had a lot of
componenttext: Yes. This is Marc. Like for like actually is Siemens is negligibly impacting us. That mean, they aren't selling a whole lot of stuff. They aren't selling a lot of tech resale. From a booking's perspective, there's not a lot of -- they haven't had a lot of individual sales of their -- of what they offer separately. Almost anything that has been driven by that base has been migration-related. So I think you might take a few percent out of it to be -- if you want to relative to that increase. But the vast majority, certainly 95% plus is related to Cerner and sale of our solutions and our services and our ITWorks and all of those things. So if you're really looking -- if you're trying to figure out, is this bookings increase reflective of Cerner's opportunities in the marketplace? It is almost entirely related to our opportunities. Zane?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think the first place to start is by looking at the new business bookings, you have 39% new business booking for the quarter, which is all Cerner. Cerner, as Marc said, it's a few percentage points as it relates to the current year impact of Health
componenttext: And I think the first place to start is by looking at the new business bookings, you have 39% new business booking for the quarter, which is all Cerner. Cerner, as Marc said, it's a few percentage points as it relates to the current year impact of Health Services bookings on our total bookings. So it's very minimal.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then I guess the follow-up question then becomes it would seem that there has to be an elongation in the backlog to revenue recognition conversion period. When we talked about this before and you said there hasn't been a meaningful change there. I g
componenttext: Okay. Then I guess the follow-up question then becomes it would seem that there has to be an elongation in the backlog to revenue recognition conversion period. When we talked about this before and you said there hasn't been a meaningful change there. I guess can you help us bridge the gap from 32% bookings growth year-to-date likely to stay that number as we go into the end of the year to kind of revenue guidance. Like what -- you talked about the milestone payment, but you wouldn't even think that, that hasn't been impacting the business long and off to explain the change in the bookings growth rate to the rev rec, to the delta in the rev rec growth rate or just what kind of am I missing there?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, in the milestone, it's primarily impact current quarter bookings near-term and it does feed the backlog. Keep in mind this, George, this year we had significantly higher levels of long-term bookings, right. First 2 quarters were primarily -- were 35
componenttext: Well, in the milestone, it's primarily impact current quarter bookings near-term and it does feed the backlog. Keep in mind this, George, this year we had significantly higher levels of long-term bookings, right. First 2 quarters were primarily -- were 35, 37, whatever the percent was, it was significantly higher relative to the bookings. Certainly, this quarter it's more like it's back into the 31% range, which is normal on a very much bigger number. There's -- a lot of these new contracts that are getting signed by new clients had a significant amount of services and other items that roll into the backlog. So I'm not sure that it's elongating the backlog because things like software and some to your point, if I day base payments, the software never really hits the backlog. It gets recognized part mostly in the quarter which is booked and that don't have any future impact. I am now getting for milestones, for some other contract terms, I am getting backlog that is coming in from license. Now it's more of a 2 to 3-year time frame, but it varies from day 1 to that. So from an elongated backlog, yes, it's slightly longer in some cases, but it's not materially different relative to the business. So understand that the large bookings number coming through feels like it should contribute more to '16. It does contribute more. I mean 75% of my revenue in '16 out of that backlog where in prior periods, it would've been closer to 70%. So I'm getting a significant -- I am getting more revenue coming through there. But it is -- the mix is similar except I have a lot more long-term this year than I've had in prior years. And that is going to -- that's all 10 years stuff that is going to basically add to the overall average number of years it takes to drive a backlog out.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Then maybe one last quick question is you kind of referenced briefly that the kind of increase scale in the business now with the inclusion of Health Services. I guess should we be thinking of this 10% to 15% EPS growth as kind of th
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Then maybe one last quick question is you kind of referenced briefly that the kind of increase scale in the business now with the inclusion of Health Services. I guess should we be thinking of this 10% to 15% EPS growth as kind of the new normal target range for the company? Or is 15% to 20% closer to the right range? I guess what's I'm trying to think about what do we think is the sustainable number now given the kind of the new size of the business and given the growth profile of the legacy Siemens business.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I do not intend that the current -- the 2016 guidance for revenue and margins -- earnings are growing at the same rate to be indicative of what we look to do in the future. We are a business that should have leverage. Keep in mind, we are growing off
componenttext: Yes. I do not intend that the current -- the 2016 guidance for revenue and margins -- earnings are growing at the same rate to be indicative of what we look to do in the future. We are a business that should have leverage. Keep in mind, we are growing off of the 2015 that we put in Siemens. And so, certainly, that helps us. But now in '16, we're r growing on top of that. So we are having to go grow revenue on top of the 30% revenue growth business. I have to grow earnings on top of the 26% earnings growth business. So there is -- it isn't illogical that in the year following that significant amount of growth, particularly in the year I'm getting hit with these noncash expenses, that the growth might more track with revenue. I think, over time, we look to grow revenue double-digit. And then you would see us moving that earnings percentage growth up higher than our revenue growth. We will get leverage out way. The bigger the company we get, software companies we get more efficient on in our services businesses. As we roll to continue to rollout the model system, which is an effective way to go implement our software. As we look to go make very quick migrations of Siemens clients. I think there's a lot of opportunities for us to certainly get efficiency in the business. So yes, I wouldn't -- I'm not calling this the new normal. There's upside to our growth percentages.

componenttextpreview: The bookings comp, since HS doesn't have a whole lot of impact, pure HS on the bookings, it won't really be a reason. But given, as we talked earlier, that overall bookings are growing 30%, I call that a pretty reasonable compTo grow above. But yes, no,
componenttext:
The bookings comp, since HS doesn't have a whole lot of impact, pure HS on the bookings, it won't really be a reason. But given, as we talked earlier, that overall bookings are growing 30%, I call that a pretty reasonable comp
To grow above. But yes, no, it's a tough comp. But I think keep in mind that most of the growth this year was pretty much organic. It wasn't impacted a lot by HS on the booking side. Certainly, on the earnings and revenue side, it was impacted. But on the booking side, it wasn't. So we grew 30% relatively organically on the bookings side. We see a very active marketplace, so that -- our goal is to grow on top of that 30% uptick in bookings we saw in 2015.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Got you. And just quickly on the contracts. So I mean you mentioned strong growth in large contracts. And it looks like contracts over $10 million have already exceeded 2014. Can you give just a little bit more color on what's driving those and how that compared to you expectations going into the year?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. I think what you're seeing is we had a large number of big systems making purchases. So talk about competitiveness in the IDN marketplace and the investor owned marketplace. And so just a pure very large new business and current clients of t
componenttext: This is Zane. I think what you're seeing is we had a large number of big systems making purchases. So talk about competitiveness in the IDN marketplace and the investor owned marketplace. And so just a pure very large new business and current clients of that are out procuring solutions to standardized their businesses as they move forward on a standard platform and using Cerner to help drive cost down and leverage, create leverage for their organizations. I think some of those larger contracts are all about actually creating leverage in their organization. So whether it's ITWorks type situations where our clients are utilizing our scale to help drive costs appropriately on their side and prepare for the future elements. I think some of those larger elements are reflective of a broad base of the business because we hit on pretty much every large contract in that space, big IDNs, investor owned or ITWorks businesses, our regional and community Hospital marketplace, they're going to drive a significant large upfront bookings. But I think it's a combination of things, and it's really about our clients are preparing for the future of health care. And that's what we are helping to provide them to help drive their cost down and to improve the quality of care.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you just run through for me one more time the factors behind the reduction in the fourth quarter guidance? And also as a follow-up, what are the cash flow expectations for 2016 now that you've sort of set the stage for the income statement?
componenttext: Could you just run through for me one more time the factors behind the reduction in the fourth quarter guidance? And also as a follow-up, what are the cash flow expectations for 2016 now that you've sort of set the stage for the income statement?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, relative to Q4, I think we continue to see lower revenue for Q4. I'm not looking to go -- we hit services revenue in Q3. We've probably expected Q4 to grow a little bit from that number. I think our current projections, based on the timing of
componenttext: Sure. Well, relative to Q4, I think we continue to see lower revenue for Q4. I'm not looking to go -- we hit services revenue in Q3. We've probably expected Q4 to grow a little bit from that number. I think our current projections, based on the timing of hiring new people and based on the work is that Q4 would be relatively flat on the services side to Q3. So we're not looking to go increase that significant amount. And I think we'll still see some of the impact to this milestone-based payments on contracts. It's going to have an impact on the timing of revenue recognition. So those are elements that as we look forward to the revenue coming out of Q4 that we expect it to be -- to probably be about $50 million lower probably from the midpoint as to what has previously been out there. Half of that is probably HS continuing to be lower than we projected, and the other half is basically Cerner professional services and some of our -- those Q3 elements rolling into Q4. So that's the primary difference you're going to see relative to the Q4 number. On the cash flow side, I think the -- we -- in Q4, we would expect we have some larger cash CapEx items related to buildings that will hit us in Q4. So we would expect to kind of end the year at about 475 -- 470,000 -- $470 million of total CapEx, including software CapEx. Next year, we probably have be a little bit of an uptick on that as we finish out our trails building. One of the key things in '15 is we are purchasing our data center building. We currently lease that and given that all of the data center activity that we have there, we want to own our future there. We don't want to be subject to the vagaries of the landlord, which has been a very good landlord to us, but we want to own of that facility. So I think we've got, so as you look at this year, we end up with about $405 million of CapEx, about $275 million of software CapEx and there's probably increment up a little bit as we go into 2016.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Correct.Well, with that, I'd like to close -- maybe just step back a little bit to kind of provide a little perspective. We certainly understand our accountability to deliver against all our metrics but Zane's commentary around our bookings and our curr
componenttext:
Correct.
Well, with that, I'd like to close -- maybe just step back a little bit to kind of provide a little perspective. We certainly understand our accountability to deliver against all our metrics but Zane's commentary around our bookings and our current position in the marketplace gives us confidence regarding our success in that marketplace. We've been at this a very long time and one thing we've always been driven by is the kind of deliver on the bigger mission. We are focused on long-term value but also in pretty good about delivering against near-term expectations. I think we're incredibly well-positioned to become a large company. It's not going to be a really perfectly straight path, but where we are situated between healthcare and IT, I think, gives us a lot of opportunities. We are investing $700 million a year in R&D to address those opportunities. And I think that level of investment especially when you look at it in the context of other people trying to buy things that they're going to put together is impressive and will generate a long-term benefit and advantage for us. Many of you had a chance to attend our healthcare conference where we had 14,000 attendees focused on solving major issues in healthcare. It's hard to come out of that conference not being energized with the belief that we are on the right track. We actually now just getting to some of the fun stuff with the base level of digitization in healthcare using data, predictive analytics. We think this can have a real disruptive impact on quality and outcomes and payment models, and we expect to be right in the middle of that disruption. What we do is hard and it's complex, but we think we're well-positioned and certainly I wouldn't trade our position for anybody else's. Thanks for listening, and have a good evening.
